amass Tool


amass is a powerful open-source tool used for DNS enumeration, subdomain discovery, and network mapping. It is widely used by security researchers and penetration testers for finding hidden subdomains, mapping out attack surfaces, and performing reconnaissance during penetration testing and bug bounty hunting.



What does amass do?


amass is designed to perform a variety of tasks related to domain enumeration and information gathering, including:


    
    
  • Subdomain Discovery: Discovers subdomains through a combination of DNS resolution, brute-forcing, and data collection from multiple sources.
    • 
    
  • DNS Enumeration: Resolves DNS records to gather information on a target domain and its subdomains.
    • 
    
  • Passive Reconnaissance: Collects DNS records and subdomain information from public sources without making direct requests to the target domain.
    • 
    
  • Active Reconnaissance: Actively queries DNS servers and performs aggressive brute-forcing of subdomains to identify additional targets.
    • 
    
  • Data Integration: Integrates data from a wide range of sources, including search engines, DNS, certificate transparency logs, and more.
    • 
    
  • Network Mapping: Creates a map of the domain infrastructure by mapping out domains and their subdomains, helping identify potential vulnerabilities.
    • 




Key Features of amass


    
    
  • Subdomain Discovery: amass uses various techniques like brute-forcing, DNS resolution, and querying third-party services to discover subdomains.
    • 
    
  • Data Collection: amass aggregates data from a variety of public and private sources, such as WHOIS databases, DNS records, search engines, and certificate transparency logs.
    • 
    
  • Passive and Active Enumeration: amass supports both passive and active techniques for discovering subdomains and resolving DNS records.
    • 
    
  • Customizable Reconnaissance: It allows users to configure custom data sources, configure brute-force wordlists, and adjust scanning parameters.
    • 
    
  • API Integration: amass integrates with APIs of popular services like Shodan, Censys, and VirusTotal to enhance the data collection process.
    • 
    
  • Speed and Performance: amass is designed to be efficient and fast, even when working with large datasets or scanning entire networks.
    • 
    
  • Comprehensive Output Formats: amass supports a variety of output formats, including JSON, to facilitate further analysis or integration with other tools.
    • 




Use Cases


amass is effective for a range of tasks, particularly in security research, penetration testing, and bug bounty hunting. Common use cases include:


    
    
  • Subdomain Discovery: amass is ideal for discovering subdomains, which can provide additional attack surfaces during penetration testing or bug bounty hunts.
    • 
    
  • DNS Enumeration: It is used to enumerate DNS records to gather information about a target domain's infrastructure, including nameservers, mail servers, and other services.
    • 
    
  • Reconnaissance: Security researchers use amass for both active and passive reconnaissance to gather information before launching more targeted attacks.
    • 
    
  • Attack Surface Mapping: amass is valuable for mapping out the attack surface of a domain, helping researchers identify subdomains and services that may be vulnerable to exploitation.
    • 
    
  • Bug Bounty Hunting: Researchers use amass to find subdomains and DNS misconfigurations, which may lead to discovering vulnerabilities in web applications or services.
    • 




Basic Usage


Here are some basic usage examples:



Run amass to discover subdomains for a domain:


amass enum -d example.com



This command runs amass in enumeration mode to discover subdomains for example.com.



Run amass with a specific subdomain wordlist:


amass enum -d example.com -w subdomains.txt



This command uses a custom wordlist (subdomains.txt) to discover subdomains for example.com.



Save output in JSON format:


amass enum -d example.com -json output.json



This command will save the discovered subdomains and DNS records in a JSON file (output.json).



Run amass in active mode:


amass enum -d example.com -active



This command performs active enumeration to find subdomains and DNS records by directly querying DNS servers.



Advanced Usage


amass also supports advanced features such as:


    
    
  • Brute-Forcing: amass can use a custom wordlist to brute-force subdomains, helping discover additional subdomains that may not be publicly listed.
    • 
    
  • Custom Data Sources: amass allows users to add custom data sources for reconnaissance, such as integrating APIs from external services like Shodan, Censys, and VirusTotal.
    • 
    
  • Scope Management: amass supports advanced scope management, allowing users to control which domains, subdomains, or networks are included or excluded during enumeration.
    • 
    
  • Parallel Enumeration: amass supports concurrent requests to speed up the discovery process, allowing researchers to scan large sets of domains or IP ranges quickly.
    • 
    
  • Data Export: amass provides support for exporting data in multiple formats, such as JSON, CSV, and text, for easy integration into other workflows or tools.
    • 



            
            
          

  
    Basic Enum
    Passive
    Active
    Save Output
    Wordlist
    ASN Enum
    Brute Force
    IP Range
    Crawl
    Monitor
    Help

    
    
      
        amass enum -d example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        amass enum -d example.com -passive
      
      
    

    
      
        amass enum -d example.com -active
      
      
    

    
      
        amass enum -d example.com -o subdomains.txt
      
      
    

    
      
        amass enum -d example.com -w wordlist.txt
      
      
    

    
      
        amass intel -asn 12345
      
      
    

    
      
        amass enum -d example.com --brute
      
      
    

    
      
        amass intel -addr 192.168.0.0/24
      
      
    

    
      
        amass enum -d example.com -src
      
      
    

    
      
        amass track -d example.com
      
      
    

    
    
      
        Amass Official Documentation
      
      
    
  



              


              


                
                

                 

                   
subfinder Tool


subfinder is a fast and reliable subdomain enumeration tool that helps security researchers, penetration testers, and bug bounty hunters discover subdomains for a given domain. It is developed as part of Project Discovery and is widely used to gather information during the reconnaissance phase of a security assessment.



What does subfinder do?


subfinder is designed to perform subdomain enumeration by leveraging passive information gathering techniques. It queries various sources, including DNS records, certificate transparency logs, and search engines, to discover subdomains associated with a target domain. Key tasks performed by subfinder include:


    
    
  • Subdomain Discovery: Finds subdomains for a given domain by querying public sources, DNS servers, and various APIs.
    • 
    
  • Passive Reconnaissance: Subfinder relies on passive data collection, meaning it does not directly interact with the target domain or send requests to it, making it stealthy and safe.
    • 
    
  • High-Speed Enumeration: It is optimized for performance, making it faster than other subdomain enumeration tools.
    • 
    
  • Custom Data Sources: Supports integration with various data sources, such as DNS services, public databases, and third-party APIs, to improve subdomain discovery.
    • 
    
  • Domain Takeover Detection: Identifies potential subdomains that might be vulnerable to takeover.
    • 




Key Features of subfinder


    
    
  • Fast and Efficient: subfinder is optimized for speed and efficiency, capable of handling large datasets and quickly discovering subdomains.
    • 
    
  • Passive Enumeration: Uses a wide range of passive techniques to enumerate subdomains without directly interacting with the target domain, ensuring that the target is not alerted to the enumeration.
    • 
    
  • Support for Multiple Data Sources: Integrates with many third-party services such as VirusTotal, DNSdumpster, and SecurityTrails, to provide comprehensive results.
    • 
    
  • Customizable: Users can configure subfinder to work with different wordlists, DNS servers, and data sources based on their needs.
    • 
    
  • Domain Takeover Risk Detection: subfinder helps identify subdomains that could potentially be taken over by an attacker if the corresponding resources or services are left unclaimed.
    • 
    
  • Fast Integration: Subfinder is ideal for integrating into larger automated workflows, especially for security researchers and bug bounty hunters looking to automate reconnaissance tasks.
    • 




Use Cases


subfinder is useful for a variety of tasks, particularly in the context of security research, penetration testing, and bug bounty hunting. Some common use cases include:


    
    
  • Subdomain Discovery: subfinder is commonly used to discover subdomains associated with a target domain, uncovering additional attack surfaces.
    • 
    
  • Reconnaissance: Security researchers and penetration testers use subfinder for gathering detailed domain information during the reconnaissance phase of an engagement.
    • 
    
  • Bug Bounty Hunting: Bug bounty hunters use subfinder to identify vulnerable subdomains and report them as potential security risks.
    • 
    
  • DNS Misconfigurations: Subdomain enumeration using subfinder can help identify misconfigured DNS records, leading to the discovery of vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • Domain Takeover Vulnerability Detection: By identifying subdomains that are no longer active, subfinder helps in detecting potential domain takeover vulnerabilities.
    • 




Basic Usage


Here are some basic usage examples for subfinder:



Discover subdomains for a domain:


subfinder -d example.com



This command will enumerate all subdomains associated with example.com using passive sources.



Run subfinder with multiple domains:


subfinder -d example.com -d example2.com



This command will enumerate subdomains for both example.com and example2.com.



Use a custom wordlist for subdomain discovery:


subfinder -d example.com -w subdomains.txt



This command uses a custom wordlist (subdomains.txt) to discover subdomains for example.com.



Save the output to a file:


subfinder -d example.com -o output.txt



This command saves the discovered subdomains to a file named output.txt.



Run subfinder with integration to additional APIs:


subfinder -d example.com -o output.txt -v



With the -v flag, subfinder will display detailed information about the subdomains found, including data from integrated APIs.



Advanced Usage


subfinder also supports advanced features, including:


    
    
  • Custom DNS Servers: Users can specify custom DNS servers to resolve subdomains, providing flexibility for different network configurations.
    • 
    
  • Third-Party API Integration: subfinder integrates with services like VirusTotal, SecurityTrails, and others to gather additional information about subdomains.
    • 
    
  • Domain Takeover Detection: It helps identify subdomains that are not pointing to active services and may be vulnerable to takeover.
    • 
    
  • Output Formats: subfinder supports various output formats, including plain text and JSON, which can be easily integrated with other tools and scripts.
    • 
    
  • Concurrency and Speed: The tool is designed for speed and can handle multiple domains and large lists of subdomains in parallel, making it fast for large-scale enumeration tasks.
    • 




              


  
    Basic Enum
    Passive
    Active
    Save Output
    Wordlist
    Brute Force
    ASN Enum
    IP Range
    Monitor
    Help

    
    
      
        subfinder -d example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        subfinder -d example.com -passive
      
      
    

    
      
        subfinder -d example.com -active
      
      
    

    
      
        subfinder -d example.com -o subdomains.txt
      
      
    

    
      
        subfinder -d example.com -w wordlist.txt
      
      
    

    
      
        subfinder -d example.com --brute
      
      
    

    
      
        subfinder -d example.com -asn 12345
      
      
    

    
      
        subfinder -d example.com -ip-range 192.168.1.0/24
      
      
    

    
      
        subfinder -d example.com -src
      
      
    

    
    
      
        Subfinder Official Documentation
      
      
    
  



              

              

                
                

assetfinder Tool


assetfinder is an open-source tool designed to help security researchers, penetration testers, and bug bounty hunters identify assets (such as subdomains) associated with a given domain. It is particularly useful for quickly finding associated domains, subdomains, and other valuable attack surface information to aid in the reconnaissance phase of a security assessment.



What does assetfinder do?


assetfinder is a subdomain discovery tool that helps to identify the various assets related to a target domain. The tool leverages multiple data sources to perform passive subdomain enumeration, allowing security professionals to quickly discover potential targets for further analysis. Key tasks performed by assetfinder include:


    
    
  • Subdomain Discovery: Assetfinder uses a combination of techniques and data sources to find subdomains associated with a target domain.
    • 
    
  • Passive Reconnaissance: It gathers subdomains and other assets through passive means without directly interacting with the target, ensuring stealthy enumeration.
    • 
    
  • API Integration: Assetfinder integrates with several external APIs, including those from popular services like VirusTotal and Shodan, to collect additional information on domains and subdomains.
    • 
    
  • High-Speed Enumeration: The tool is optimized for fast enumeration, making it efficient even when scanning large domains or networks.
    • 
    
  • Discovery of Associated Domains: In addition to subdomains, assetfinder can find domains and related resources that might be overlooked in manual assessments.
    • 




Key Features of assetfinder


    
    
  • Fast Subdomain Discovery: Assetfinder is designed to quickly discover subdomains for a given target using a variety of sources and techniques, including brute-forcing and querying APIs.
    • 
    
  • Passive Enumeration: The tool performs passive reconnaissance, making it ideal for stealthily gathering subdomains without alerting the target.
    • 
    
  • API Integration: Assetfinder integrates with third-party APIs like VirusTotal, Shodan, and others, to retrieve information about associated subdomains and domains.
    • 
    
  • Customizable: Users can configure assetfinder to use custom wordlists and define DNS sources to better tailor the tool to their specific needs.
    • 
    
  • Comprehensive Data Collection: Assetfinder aggregates data from multiple sources to provide a comprehensive set of results during subdomain discovery.
    • 
    
  • Simple and Lightweight: The tool is lightweight, easy to use, and does not require complex setup or configuration to get started.
    • 




Use Cases


assetfinder is widely used for various reconnaissance and information-gathering tasks, especially during penetration tests and bug bounty hunting. Some common use cases include:


    
    
  • Subdomain Discovery: Assetfinder helps security professionals quickly discover subdomains associated with a domain, increasing the number of potential attack vectors to explore.
    • 
    
  • Reconnaissance: Security researchers use assetfinder to gather detailed information on target domains by identifying hidden assets and subdomains.
    • 
    
  • Domain Takeover Vulnerability Detection: Assetfinder is helpful in discovering subdomains that might be vulnerable to domain takeover if they are no longer in use or not properly configured.
    • 
    
  • Bug Bounty Hunting: Bug bounty hunters use assetfinder to find subdomains and associated assets of a target domain to identify vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • DNS Misconfiguration Detection: The tool is valuable for finding subdomains that may be misconfigured or exposed unintentionally, leading to potential vulnerabilities.
    • 




Basic Usage


Here are some basic usage examples for assetfinder:



Discover subdomains for a domain:


assetfinder example.com



This command will attempt to find subdomains associated with example.com by querying passive data sources.



Save the results to a file:


assetfinder example.com > output.txt



This command will save the discovered subdomains for example.com to a file named output.txt.



Discover subdomains and associated domains for multiple domains:


assetfinder example1.com example2.com



This command will find subdomains for both example1.com and example2.com.



Use assetfinder with custom DNS sources:


assetfinder -dns  example.com



This command allows you to specify a custom DNS server for resolving subdomains of example.com.



Use assetfinder with API integration:


assetfinder -v example.com



The -v flag enables verbose mode, displaying detailed information from API integrations, such as data from VirusTotal and Shodan.



Advanced Usage


assetfinder also supports advanced usage for more tailored subdomain discovery:


    
    
  • Custom Wordlists: Users can configure assetfinder to use custom wordlists for brute-forcing subdomains, improving the chances of discovering hidden subdomains.
    • 
    
  • Domain Takeover Detection: Assetfinder helps identify subdomains that may be vulnerable to domain takeover, typically because they no longer point to active resources or have been abandoned.
    • 
    
  • API Key Configuration: For users leveraging third-party APIs like VirusTotal, Shodan, and others, assetfinder can be configured to use an API key to increase the number of requests and enhance data retrieval.
    • 
    
  • Custom DNS Servers: In cases where custom DNS servers need to be queried, assetfinder can be configured to resolve subdomains through specific DNS servers.
    • 
    
  • Parallel Requests: Assetfinder can issue concurrent requests to multiple sources for faster subdomain enumeration, making it effective for large-scale domain assessments.
    • 




              
   

  
    Basic Enum
    Passive
    Active
    Save Output
    Wordlist
    Brute Force
    ASN Enum
    IP Range
    Monitor
    Help

    
    
      
        assetfinder example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        assetfinder -passive example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        assetfinder -active example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        assetfinder -o assets.txt example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        assetfinder -w wordlist.txt example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        assetfinder -brute example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        assetfinder -asn 12345 example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        assetfinder -ip-range 192.168.1.0/24 example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        assetfinder -src example.com
      
      
    

    
    
      
        Assetfinder Official Documentation
      
      
    
  






                

              


                
                
            
dnsgen Tool


dnsgen is a powerful subdomain generation tool used by security researchers, penetration testers, and bug bounty hunters for discovering subdomains. It is designed to generate possible subdomains by applying various wordlists, mutations, and permutations to a base domain. This tool is useful in the enumeration phase of security assessments and can help uncover hidden assets that could be potential attack surfaces.



What does dnsgen do?


dnsgen is used to generate a list of potential subdomains for a target domain. It applies various techniques, including permutations of known subdomain prefixes and suffixes, using wordlists or custom input to generate subdomain names. The goal is to predict subdomains that might not be found through traditional passive enumeration techniques, such as querying DNS records or certificate transparency logs. Some of the key tasks performed by dnsgen include:


    
    
  • Subdomain Generation: dnsgen generates a list of potential subdomains by applying permutations to a base domain. This allows you to discover subdomains that might not be registered or publicly available.
    • 
    
  • Wordlist-Based Mutation: The tool uses a wordlist-based approach, combining common subdomain prefixes and suffixes to generate a comprehensive list of potential subdomains.
    • 
    
  • Customizable Wordlists: Users can provide their own custom wordlists to improve the accuracy of subdomain generation, based on the target domain and known patterns.
    • 
    
  • Efficient Subdomain Discovery: The tool is optimized to generate large lists of subdomains quickly, helping researchers find hidden subdomains in a short amount of time.
    • 
    
  • Integration with Other Tools: dnsgen can be used in conjunction with other subdomain enumeration tools like assetfinder or subfinder for a more comprehensive subdomain discovery process.
    • 




Key Features of dnsgen


    
    
  • Custom Wordlist Support: dnsgen allows you to specify custom wordlists to generate subdomains more accurately based on known prefixes and suffixes.
    • 
    
  • Efficient Permutation Generation: The tool generates permutations of subdomains quickly, helping security researchers discover subdomains that may not be easily found using passive techniques.
    • 
    
  • Combines Multiple Techniques: dnsgen combines brute-forcing and wordlist-based mutations to generate subdomains, increasing the likelihood of uncovering hidden assets.
    • 
    
  • Fast and Lightweight: dnsgen is optimized for speed and can handle large sets of potential subdomains, generating results efficiently.
    • 
    
  • Easy Integration: dnsgen can be integrated into automated workflows, working alongside other tools to enhance the reconnaissance process.
    • 




Use Cases


dnsgen is commonly used for discovering subdomains that may not be found using other tools or techniques. It is particularly useful in the following scenarios:


    
    
  • Subdomain Brute Forcing: dnsgen is used to brute-force subdomains using permutations of a base domain, helping security researchers discover hidden or unregistered subdomains.
    • 
    
  • Subdomain Discovery: During penetration testing or bug bounty hunting, dnsgen is used to find subdomains that could potentially expose vulnerabilities or misconfigurations.
    • 
    
  • Domain Enumeration: dnsgen helps enumerate potential subdomains for a target domain, providing a comprehensive set of assets for further analysis and testing.
    • 
    
  • DNS Misconfigurations: The tool can help identify subdomains that might be misconfigured, creating additional attack surfaces for an organization.
    • 
    
  • Mapping Attack Surfaces: dnsgen helps in creating a comprehensive map of all potential subdomains, which can then be tested for vulnerabilities.
    • 




Basic Usage


Here are some basic usage examples for dnsgen:



Generate subdomains for a domain:


dnsgen example.com



This command will generate potential subdomains for example.com using the default wordlist and permutation techniques.



Generate subdomains using a custom wordlist:


dnsgen -w custom-wordlist.txt example.com



This command will generate subdomains for example.com using the custom wordlist custom-wordlist.txt.



Save the generated subdomains to a file:


dnsgen example.com > subdomains.txt



This command will save the generated list of subdomains for example.com to a file named subdomains.txt.



Generate subdomains with verbose output:


dnsgen -v example.com



The -v flag enables verbose output, providing additional details about the subdomains being generated.



Generate subdomains with a custom suffix:


dnsgen -s sub.example.com example.com



This command will generate subdomains for example.com with the suffix sub.example.com added to each permutation.



Advanced Usage


dnsgen also supports advanced features to help improve subdomain generation:


    
    
  • Custom Wordlists: You can use a custom wordlist to generate subdomains that align more closely with known patterns or specific target criteria.
    • 
    
  • Brute-Force Mode: dnsgen can generate subdomains through brute-force techniques, making it possible to uncover even the most obscure subdomains.
    • 
    
  • Integration with Other Tools: dnsgen can be combined with other subdomain enumeration tools like subfinder, assetfinder, or amass to provide a more comprehensive list of discovered subdomains.
    • 
    
  • Parallelization: dnsgen can be run in parallel with other processes to speed up subdomain generation when working with large datasets or multiple targets.
    • 



              
   

  
    Basic Enum
    Custom Wordlist
    Brute Force
    Wildcard
    Reverse DNS
    DNS Lookup
    Verbose Output
    Save Output
    Threading
    Help

    
    
      
        dnsgen -d example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsgen -w wordlist.txt -d example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsgen -b example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsgen -w wordlist.txt -d example.com -wildcard
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsgen -r example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsgen -l example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsgen -v example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsgen -o output.txt example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsgen -t 100 example.com
      
      
    

    
    
      
        DNSgen Official Documentation
      
      
    
  




              

              

                
                

           
massdns Tool


massdns is a high-performance DNS resolver and subdomain enumeration tool designed for quickly resolving large lists of domain names. It is particularly useful for security researchers, penetration testers, and bug bounty hunters who need to perform large-scale DNS queries for domain reconnaissance, subdomain discovery, and DNS-based security testing. Massdns is optimized for speed and scalability, allowing users to efficiently handle vast amounts of DNS queries in a short time.



What does massdns do?


massdns is a fast DNS resolver designed to handle massive amounts of DNS requests in parallel. It is commonly used to resolve domain names and subdomains, quickly retrieving DNS records such as A, AAAA, and CNAME records. Massdns is especially effective when working with large lists of domains, allowing security professionals to resolve multiple domain names simultaneously. Some key tasks performed by massdns include:


    
    
  • High-Speed DNS Resolution: massdns is designed for fast and scalable DNS resolution, capable of handling large lists of domain names in parallel to provide results quickly.
    • 
    
  • Subdomain Enumeration: It can be used in conjunction with other tools to resolve subdomains discovered through brute-forcing or passive enumeration, speeding up the reconnaissance process.
    • 
    
  • Customizable DNS Querying: Users can customize the types of DNS records queried (e.g., A, AAAA, CNAME), making it suitable for various use cases, such as finding IP addresses or identifying domain configurations.
    • 
    
  • Support for Multiple DNS Servers: massdns supports querying multiple DNS servers concurrently, improving the speed and reliability of resolution.
    • 
    
  • DNS Data Collection: massdns can be used to collect DNS data for analysis, including identifying records associated with a target domain or subdomain.
    • 




Key Features of massdns


    
    
  • High Performance: massdns is optimized for performance, capable of resolving millions of DNS queries per second using parallel processing, making it ideal for large-scale DNS resolution.
    • 
    
  • Custom DNS Record Querying: massdns allows users to specify the type of DNS records to resolve, such as A, AAAA, MX, and CNAME records, for more targeted reconnaissance.
    • 
    
  • Customizable and Flexible: massdns provides various configuration options, including specifying custom DNS servers, using different wordlists, and applying custom resolvers.
    • 
    
  • Concurrent DNS Server Queries: massdns can query multiple DNS servers in parallel, making the tool faster and more reliable, especially when dealing with large-scale domain resolution.
    • 
    
  • Support for Subdomain Brute Forcing: massdns can be used as part of subdomain brute-forcing workflows, resolving domains generated through brute-forcing tools like dnsgen or amass.
    • 
    
  • Efficient for Large Lists: massdns excels in scenarios where large lists of domain names need to be resolved quickly, such as during security assessments or bug bounty hunting.
    • 




Use Cases


massdns is commonly used in various security research tasks, including but not limited to:


    
    
  • Subdomain Resolution: massdns can quickly resolve a list of subdomains discovered during passive or active reconnaissance, making it easier to identify live services and resources associated with a domain.
    • 
    
  • DNS Enumeration: The tool is useful for enumerating DNS records across multiple domains, helping security professionals identify key assets and configurations.
    • 
    
  • DNS Security Testing: massdns can be used to detect DNS misconfigurations, identify vulnerable DNS records, and gather DNS data to look for potential security weaknesses in target domains.
    • 
    
  • Large-Scale Domain Scanning: When working with large-scale domain name lists, massdns can resolve domains in bulk efficiently, making it ideal for large-scale network assessments.
    • 
    
  • DNS-Based Information Gathering: Security researchers use massdns to gather important DNS records, which can be used for further penetration testing or vulnerability assessment.
    • 




Basic Usage


Here are some basic usage examples for massdns:



Resolve DNS records for a domain list:


massdns -r resolvers.txt -t A -o S result.txt example1.com example2.com



This command resolves A records for example1.com and example2.com using DNS resolvers listed in resolvers.txt. The results will be saved in result.txt.



Resolve subdomains discovered with a wordlist:


massdns -r resolvers.txt -t A -o S -w subdomains.txt result.txt



This command resolves A records for a list of subdomains from subdomains.txt using the DNS resolvers in resolvers.txt and outputs the results to result.txt.



Resolve different types of DNS records:


massdns -r resolvers.txt -t MX -o S result.txt example.com



This command resolves MX records for example.com and saves the results in result.txt.



Display results in JSON format:


massdns -r resolvers.txt -t A -o J result.json example.com



This command resolves A records for example.com and outputs the results in JSON format to result.json.



Limit the number of parallel DNS queries:


massdns -r resolvers.txt -t A -o S -p 100 example.com



This command resolves A records for example.com, limiting the number of parallel queries to 100.



Advanced Usage


massdns also supports advanced features for more specific or large-scale DNS resolution tasks:


    
    
  • Custom Resolver Lists: Users can provide custom lists of DNS resolvers to be used in queries, improving the speed and accuracy of DNS resolution.
    • 
    
  • Multi-Record Querying: massdns can query different types of DNS records, such as A, AAAA, MX, and CNAME, allowing users to retrieve more comprehensive DNS data.
    • 
    
  • Output Formatting: The tool supports different output formats, including simple text, JSON, and CSV, making it easy to process results in automated workflows.
    • 
    
  • Querying Multiple Domains: massdns can resolve DNS records for multiple domains and subdomains simultaneously, speeding up large-scale scans.
    • 
    
  • Rate Limiting and Parallelism: Users can configure rate limits and adjust the number of parallel queries to optimize DNS resolution based on available resources and the size of the domain list.
    • 
    
  • Integration with Other Tools: massdns can be used alongside other reconnaissance and enumeration tools to resolve subdomains discovered via brute-forcing or passive enumeration, enhancing the overall information-gathering process.
    • 



              

              



  
    Basic Enum
    Use Wordlist
    IP Lookup
    Brute Force
    Custom Output
    Parallel Queries
    Use Proxy
    Save Results
    Verbose Output
    Help

    
    
      
        massdns -t A example.com -o J
      
      
    

    
      
        massdns -w wordlist.txt -t A example.com -o J
      
      
    

    
      
        massdns -r resolver_list.txt -w subdomains.txt -o J
      
      
    

    
      
        massdns -w wordlist.txt -t A example.com -o J -b
      
      
    

    
      
        massdns -w wordlist.txt -t A example.com -o J -p
      
      
    

    
      
        massdns -w wordlist.txt -t A example.com -o J -T 100
      
      
    

    
      
        massdns -w wordlist.txt -t A example.com -o J -p proxy-list.txt
      
      
    

    
      
        massdns -w wordlist.txt -t A example.com -o J -b -P 1000
      
      
    

    
      
        massdns -w wordlist.txt -t A example.com -o J -v
      
      
    

    
    
      
        MassDNS Official Documentation
      
      
    
  





              

              


                

                
                



                   
httprobe Tool


httprobe is a simple and efficient tool for probing and verifying HTTP/HTTPS status codes of a list of URLs. It is commonly used in web application security assessments to check whether URLs are accessible over HTTP or HTTPS. The tool is designed to quickly determine which URLs are active, responsive, and which protocols (HTTP or HTTPS) they support, making it highly useful for web scraping, reconnaissance, and vulnerability scanning.



What does httprobe do?


httprobe takes a list of domain names or URLs and checks each one to see if it is accessible over HTTP or HTTPS. It sends HTTP requests to the given URLs and reports back with the protocol status (HTTP or HTTPS) and the corresponding HTTP status code (e.g., 200, 301, 404). It’s commonly used by security researchers, bug bounty hunters, and penetration testers to identify which sites are live, which are secured via HTTPS, and which may have security or misconfiguration issues.



Key Features of httprobe


    
    
  • Fast Probing: httprobe is designed to perform fast HTTP/HTTPS checks, quickly probing a large list of URLs and providing results in a short amount of time.
    • 
    
  • HTTP/HTTPS Detection: The tool checks if a domain is accessible over both HTTP and HTTPS, which is useful for identifying websites that may have mixed content or incorrect HTTPS configurations.
    • 
    
  • Status Code Reporting: httprobe outputs HTTP status codes for each URL, helping to identify whether a domain is active, redirects, or if it’s throwing errors like 404 or 500.
    • 
    
  • URL Validation: It also validates the input list by checking whether the URL is properly formatted, ensuring that the URLs tested are accessible.
    • 
    
  • Simple Output Format: The tool outputs the results in a simple and clear format, displaying URLs that are accessible over HTTP or HTTPS along with their status codes.
    • 
    
  • Integration with Other Tools: httprobe is often used as part of larger reconnaissance workflows, such as in conjunction with subdomain enumeration tools (e.g., subfinder or amass), to check which subdomains are live.
    • 




Use Cases


httprobe is commonly used in various security research and web application testing tasks, including but not limited to:


    
    
  • Web Application Reconnaissance: Security researchers use httprobe to check which subdomains and URLs are active and responsive, helping them identify potential targets for further testing.
    • 
    
  • HTTP vs. HTTPS Checking: httprobe is useful for identifying which sites have HTTPS enabled, which could indicate the presence of SSL/TLS configurations and potential vulnerabilities related to mixed content or improper HTTPS setup.
    • 
    
  • Probing Large Domain Lists: It is highly effective for quickly probing large lists of URLs and domains to check which ones are up, which helps streamline the information-gathering phase of penetration testing or bug bounty hunting.
    • 
    
  • HTTP Status Code Monitoring: The tool is used to monitor the status codes returned by URLs, which helps identify sites that may be misconfigured or have broken links (404 errors) or other issues like server misconfigurations (5xx errors).
    • 
    
  • Automated Reconnaissance: Many security professionals integrate httprobe into their automation scripts or reconnaissance pipelines to speed up their workflows when testing large sets of domains.
    • 




Basic Usage


Here are some basic usage examples for httprobe:



Probe a list of URLs:


cat domains.txt | httprobe



This command takes a list of domains from domains.txt, probes them, and outputs the HTTP/HTTPS status codes and corresponding URLs.



Probe URLs with HTTP/HTTPS and status codes:


cat domains.txt | httprobe -p



Using the -p flag will include the protocol (HTTP/HTTPS) in the output, showing which protocol each domain is accessible over.



Probe with detailed status codes:


cat domains.txt | httprobe -s



The -s flag will display the HTTP status code (e.g., 200, 301, 404) for each URL, making it easier to spot issues like redirects or errors.



Output results to a file:


cat domains.txt | httprobe > result.txt



This command will save the probing results to result.txt, allowing you to review or further analyze the list later.



Advanced Usage


httprobe also offers some advanced features for users who require more control over their probing operations:


    
    
  • Probe with custom timeout: You can set a custom timeout for HTTP requests using the -t flag to avoid waiting too long for unresponsive sites.
    • 
    
  • Custom headers: The tool supports adding custom headers to the request with the -H option, which can be helpful when dealing with sites that require specific headers (e.g., User-Agent or Accept-Language).
    • 
    
  • Handle redirects: By default, httprobe handles redirects. You can disable this behavior with the -n flag if you want to avoid following redirects during probing.
    • 
    
  • Parallelism: You can increase or decrease the number of concurrent probes using the -c flag, allowing you to adjust the speed of the tool based on your system’s capabilities.
    • 
    
  • Filtering Results: You can filter the results based on specific status codes (e.g., only show 200 OK responses) to focus on the most relevant URLs for your assessment.
    • 



                     

              


  
    Basic Scan
    Check HTTPS
    Custom Ports
    Concurrency
    Verbose Output
    File Input
    Output to File
    No Timeout
    Help

    
    
      
        httprobe example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        httprobe -p https example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        httprobe -p https,http -c 50 example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        httprobe -p https,http -c 100 example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        httprobe -p https,http -c 100 -v example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        httprobe -p https,http -c 50 -i input.txt
      
      
    

    
      
        httprobe -p https,http -c 50 -o output.txt example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        httprobe -p https,http -c 50 -t 0 example.com
      
      
    

    
    
      
        HTTProbe Official Documentation
      
      
    
  




              

              




    
		
dnsx Tool


dnsx is a versatile, fast, and efficient DNS toolkit used by security researchers and penetration testers. Developed by Project Discovery, it allows for high-performance DNS enumeration, resolution, and probing, making it an essential tool for discovering DNS-related vulnerabilities, such as subdomains and misconfigurations.



What does dnsx do?


dnsx is designed to perform a wide range of DNS-related tasks, including:


    
    
  • DNS Resolution: Resolves DNS records (A, AAAA, CNAME, TXT, MX, etc.) for a given domain or list of domains.
    • 
    
  • Subdomain Enumeration: Efficiently discovers subdomains by resolving various DNS record types.
    • 
    
  • DNS Probing: Probes specific DNS records for vulnerabilities and gathers detailed DNS information.
    • 
    
  • Wildcard DNS Filtering: Identifies and removes wildcard DNS entries from results to avoid false positives.
    • 
    
  • Brute-Force DNS Subdomains: Supports subdomain brute-forcing to discover potential hidden domains.
    • 
    
  • Speed: Built for high performance and speed, even with large DNS datasets or lists of domains.
    • 
    
  • Integration: Provides output in JSON format for easy integration into automated workflows or other security tools.
    • 




Key Features of dnsx


    
    
  • Multiple DNS Record Types: Supports querying a variety of DNS record types, including A, AAAA, CNAME, TXT, MX, and more.
    • 
    
  • Custom DNS Probing: Allows users to specify the types of DNS records to query, helping to identify misconfigurations or other vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • Wildcard DNS Filtering: Automatically detects and removes wildcard DNS responses from results, ensuring more accurate information.
    • 
    
  • Brute-Forcing: dnsx can be used to brute-force subdomains, enabling the discovery of hidden or undocumented domains that could be used for attack.
    • 
    
  • Speed and Efficiency: dnsx is designed for high-speed DNS lookups, enabling quick testing and enumeration even with large-scale datasets.
    • 
    
  • Customizable Output: Supports customizable output formats, including JSON, to facilitate integration with other tools or automation scripts.
    • 




Use Cases


dnsx is highly effective for a range of tasks, particularly in security research and bug bounty hunting. Common use cases include:


    
    
  • Subdomain Discovery: dnsx is ideal for identifying subdomains of a target domain, which can lead to finding other attack surfaces.
    • 
    
  • DNS Misconfiguration Detection: It can be used to detect issues like DNS misconfigurations, such as improper zone transfers or wildcard DNS records.
    • 
    
  • Bug Bounty Hunting: Security researchers use dnsx to collect DNS information as part of their reconnaissance efforts when hunting for vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • DNS Enumeration: dnsx allows for efficient DNS enumeration across a list of domains, helping researchers to gather comprehensive DNS data quickly.
    • 
    
  • Vulnerability Assessment: Security testers can use dnsx to examine DNS records for potential security vulnerabilities, such as outdated records or improperly configured services.
    • 




Basic Usage


Here are some basic usage examples:



Resolve A records for a list of subdomains:


cat subdomains.txt | dnsx -a -resp



This command resolves the A records for each subdomain listed in the subdomains.txt file, providing the IP addresses associated with each subdomain.



Find all DNS records for a domain:


dnsx -d example.com -all



This will resolve all available DNS records (A, AAAA, CNAME, TXT, MX, etc.) for example.com.



Brute-force subdomains with a wordlist:


dnsx -brute -w subdomains.txt -d example.com



This command uses a wordlist (subdomains.txt) to brute-force potential subdomains of example.com.



Advanced Usage


dnsx also supports advanced features such as:


    
    
  • Parallel DNS Requests: dnsx can handle multiple DNS queries concurrently, making it much faster than traditional DNS lookup tools.
    • 
    
  • Custom DNS Servers: dnsx allows users to specify custom DNS servers for resolution, which can be useful for bypassing local DNS caches or using specialized DNS services.
    • 
    
  • Wildcard DNS Filtering: Automatically detect and ignore wildcard DNS records to avoid false positives.
    • 
    
  • Output Formats: dnsx supports various output formats, including JSON, making it suitable for integration with other security tools and scripts.
    • 



    
    
    
  

  
    Basic Scan
    Custom Port
    All DNS Records
    IP Resolution
    Threading
    Output to File
    Timeout
    Multiple Domains
    Help

    
    
      
        dnsx -d example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsx -d example.com -p 53
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsx -d example.com -a -aaaa -mx -ns -txt
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsx -d example.com -ip
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsx -d example.com -threads 50
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsx -d example.com -o output.txt
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsx -d example.com -timeout 3000
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsx -d example.com,another-example.com
      
      
    

    
    
      
        DNSx Official Documentation
      
      
    
  







    
		
dnsenum Tool


dnsenum is a powerful DNS enumeration tool used for gathering information about a target domain. It automates the process of performing DNS lookups, subdomain enumeration, and gathering DNS records, making it a valuable tool for penetration testers, security researchers, and bug bounty hunters. dnsenum is designed to collect comprehensive DNS data to help identify potential attack surfaces, misconfigurations, and other security issues related to domain names.



What does dnsenum do?


dnsenum is a DNS enumeration tool that automates the process of discovering subdomains, DNS records, and other valuable information related to a target domain. It works by querying various DNS servers and performing zone transfers (if allowed) to gather comprehensive details about a domain. The tool performs several actions including:


    
    
  • Subdomain Enumeration: dnsenum can enumerate subdomains associated with a given domain, allowing security professionals to identify additional attack vectors and surface areas to test.
    • 
    
  • DNS Record Collection: dnsenum collects DNS records such as A, AAAA, MX, TXT, and CNAME records, which are crucial for understanding the target’s DNS configuration.
    • 
    
  • Zone Transfer Detection: The tool attempts to perform a DNS zone transfer to gather a complete list of domain records if the DNS server is misconfigured.
    • 
    
  • Whois Lookups: dnsenum can also gather information about the domain's WHOIS data, such as registrant, administrative contacts, and nameservers, to assist in further reconnaissance.
    • 
    
  • Brute Force Subdomain Search: The tool can brute-force subdomains by using a list of common subdomain names, which is especially useful when passive methods fail to identify subdomains.
    • 




Key Features of dnsenum


    
    
  • Comprehensive DNS Information Gathering: dnsenum helps to gather detailed DNS records and domain information that can be useful for penetration testing and vulnerability assessment.
    • 
    
  • Zone Transfer Testing: dnsenum can attempt a zone transfer to uncover hidden DNS records that could be valuable for an attacker.
    • 
    
  • Brute-Forcing Subdomains: It can use brute-forcing techniques to discover additional subdomains that may not be exposed through other means.
    • 
    
  • WHOIS Information Retrieval: dnsenum integrates WHOIS lookups, which can help uncover domain registrants, administrative contacts, and nameserver details, useful for identifying attack vectors like social engineering or domain hijacking.
    • 
    
  • Recursive DNS Lookup: It can recursively query DNS servers to gather more detailed DNS information and track down nameservers or related records.
    • 
    
  • Customizable Brute Force: dnsenum allows users to specify custom wordlists for subdomain brute-forcing, making it flexible for different environments or targets.
    • 




Use Cases


dnsenum is commonly used in various security assessments, including but not limited to:


    
    
  • Subdomain Enumeration: By discovering subdomains, dnsenum helps security professionals identify hidden or non-public subdomains that could be vulnerable to attack.
    • 
    
  • DNS Misconfiguration Detection: It assists in detecting misconfigured DNS servers that might leak sensitive information or allow unauthorized zone transfers.
    • 
    
  • Gathering DNS Records: The tool is useful for gathering DNS records such as A, AAAA, MX, and TXT, which are essential for understanding a domain’s network configuration and identifying potential vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • Domain Reconnaissance: dnsenum is frequently used during the reconnaissance phase of penetration testing to collect as much information as possible about the target domain, helping to build a profile of the infrastructure and services in use.
    • 
    
  • Automating DNS Enumeration: dnsenum automates the repetitive task of querying DNS servers, making it faster and easier to perform DNS enumeration during a security assessment.
    • 




Basic Usage


Here are some basic usage examples for dnsenum:



Enumerate subdomains for a domain:


dnsenum example.com



This command will run a basic DNS enumeration on example.com, attempting to collect DNS records, subdomains, and other information related to the domain.



Perform a zone transfer attempt:


dnsenum --zone-transfer example.com



This command attempts to perform a DNS zone transfer on example.com. If successful, it may return a full list of DNS records for the domain.



Perform brute-force subdomain enumeration:


dnsenum --subbrute example.com



This command will use a default wordlist to brute-force subdomains for example.com. The tool will attempt common subdomain names like www, mail, and others to discover more subdomains.



Specify a custom wordlist for subdomain brute-forcing:


dnsenum --subbrute --wordlist custom_wordlist.txt example.com



This command uses a custom wordlist (custom_wordlist.txt) to brute-force subdomains for example.com.



Gather WHOIS information for a domain:


dnsenum --whois example.com



This command retrieves WHOIS information for example.com, including domain registrant and nameserver details, which can be useful for further reconnaissance or social engineering attacks.



Perform a full DNS enumeration:


dnsenum --all example.com



This command performs a full DNS enumeration, including subdomain brute-forcing, zone transfer attempts, WHOIS lookups, and DNS record collection.



Advanced Usage


dnsenum also offers advanced features for users who need more control over their enumeration process:


    
    
  • Custom DNS Server: You can specify a custom DNS server to use for querying by using the -s flag, which can be useful for testing against specific DNS servers.
    • 
    
  • Filter Results: You can filter the results of the enumeration to focus on specific types of DNS records (e.g., only show MX records) by using the -r flag.
    • 
    
  • Recursive Enumeration: dnsenum supports recursive querying to gather additional information and trace nameservers or related records.
    • 
    
  • Verbose Mode: You can enable verbose output using the -v flag to get detailed information during the enumeration process.
    • 



    
    
 

  
    Basic Scan
    Brute Force
    Zone Transfer
    Find Subdomains
    Output to File
    Reverse Lookup
    Verbose Output
    Multiple Domains
    Help

    
    
      
        dnsenum example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsenum -f wordlist.txt example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsenum --zone-transfer example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsenum --enum-subdomains example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsenum -o output.txt example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsenum --reverse example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsenum -v example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        dnsenum example.com,another-example.com
      
      
    

    
    
      
        DNSenum Official Documentation
      
      
    
  







    
		
gau Tool


gau (GetAllURLs) is a tool designed to help security researchers, bug bounty hunters, and penetration testers discover all the URLs associated with a target domain. It is primarily used for gathering publicly available URLs, including historical URLs, from various sources like Wayback Machine, Common Crawl, and other publicly available databases. By providing a list of URLs, gau assists in identifying potential attack vectors, hidden pages, and areas of a website that may not be immediately visible through normal crawling methods.



What does gau do?


gau is a tool that retrieves URLs from publicly available archives, web crawls, and other sources. It helps researchers gather URLs that are either no longer indexed by search engines or not easily discoverable by traditional web crawling. The tool works by querying online archives and crawling data from sources such as:


    
    
  • Wayback Machine: A web archive that stores snapshots of websites taken at different times.
    • 
    
  • Common Crawl: A publicly accessible archive of web data that includes a wide range of URLs from web pages across the internet.
    • 
    
  • Other Sources: gau also supports retrieving URLs from other publicly available data sources, helping researchers gather as many URLs as possible for a given domain.
    • 



With the ability to pull data from multiple sources, gau is particularly useful for discovering historical URLs, subdomains, and pages that may have been removed or are hidden from standard web crawlers.



Key Features of gau


    
    
  • Historical URL Discovery: gau retrieves historical URLs from archives like the Wayback Machine, allowing security professionals to identify previously live pages or endpoints that could still be accessible.
    • 
    
  • Common Crawl Integration: The tool integrates with Common Crawl, which is an archive of the entire web that includes URLs from millions of websites, helping researchers uncover URLs that might not appear through conventional means.
    • 
    
  • Search Multiple Sources: gau is capable of querying multiple sources for URLs, improving the breadth of its URL discovery capabilities.
    • 
    
  • Filter and Process Results: The tool allows users to filter or process the results to target specific types of URLs, helping to refine searches and focus on relevant findings.
    • 
    
  • Easy Integration: gau can be easily integrated into larger web scraping or reconnaissance workflows, helping automate the process of URL gathering.
    • 




Use Cases


gau is commonly used in various stages of security assessments, including but not limited to:


    
    
  • Web Application Reconnaissance: Researchers use gau to gather URLs related to a target domain, helping them discover potentially hidden pages or endpoints that could harbor vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • Finding Vulnerable Pages: The tool is helpful in identifying previously active but now obsolete URLs that could still expose sensitive information or be leveraged in attacks.
    • 
    
  • Subdomain and Endpoint Discovery: By retrieving URLs from web archives, gau can help security professionals uncover subdomains or endpoints that are not listed in DNS records or publicly accessible.
    • 
    
  • Historical Vulnerability Research: gau can be used to identify historical instances of vulnerabilities that may have been fixed or mitigated but are still accessible via old URLs.
    • 
    
  • Reconnaissance Automation: gau is frequently incorporated into automated reconnaissance workflows to gather and process a large volume of URLs for a given domain.
    • 




Basic Usage


Here are some basic usage examples for gau:



Retrieve all URLs for a domain:


gau example.com



This command will retrieve all publicly available URLs for example.com from various sources such as Wayback Machine and Common Crawl.



Save URLs to a file:


gau example.com -o urls.txt



This command retrieves URLs for example.com and saves them to a file named urls.txt.



Retrieve URLs from Wayback Machine only:


gau --wayback example.com



This command retrieves URLs for example.com specifically from the Wayback Machine.



Retrieve URLs from Common Crawl only:


gau --commoncrawl example.com



This command retrieves URLs for example.com from Common Crawl.



Filter results to only include URLs with a specific path:


gau example.com | grep "/admin"



This command retrieves all URLs for example.com and filters the results to only show URLs that contain the path "/admin".



Combine results from multiple sources:


gau --wayback --commoncrawl example.com



This command retrieves URLs for example.com from both the Wayback Machine and Common Crawl.



Advanced Usage


gau also provides advanced options for users who need more control over the URL retrieval process:


    
    
  • Specify the number of results: You can limit the number of URLs returned by using the -n flag, which allows you to gather a specific number of results at once.
    • 
    
  • Filter URL results by status code: You can filter URLs based on their HTTP status code (e.g., only return URLs with a 200 status code) to focus on active or healthy pages.
    • 
    
  • Use custom sources: In addition to the default data sources, gau can be customized to query additional or third-party archives or databases, extending its URL discovery capability.
    • 
    
  • Parallelism: gau supports parallel requests, speeding up the process of retrieving large sets of URLs from multiple sources simultaneously.
    • 



    
    
   

  
    Basic Scan
    From Multiple Sources
    Filter by Status Code
    With Output to File
    Save Unique URLs
    Limit Number of URLs
    Verbose Output
    Multiple Domains
    Help

    
    
      
        gau example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        gau -u example.com -s https://example2.com
      
      
    

    
      
        gau example.com -c 404
      
      
    

    
      
        gau example.com -o output.txt
      
      
    

    
      
        gau example.com -u --unique
      
      
    

    
      
        gau example.com -n 50
      
      
    

    
      
        gau example.com -v
      
      
    

    
      
        gau example.com,another-example.com
      
      
    

    
    
      
        GAU Official Documentation
      
      
    
  







    
		
hakrawler Tool


hakrawler is a fast and efficient tool designed for web scraping and crawling, primarily used in web application security assessments. It helps security researchers, bug bounty hunters, and penetration testers by automatically discovering and enumerating links, forms, and other potential attack surfaces on a target website. hakrawler can quickly gather all URLs from a target website and its subdomains, making it a useful tool for reconnaissance during penetration testing or bug bounty hunting activities.



What does hakrawler do?


hakrawler is designed to help security professionals discover all accessible URLs and endpoints on a website during the reconnaissance phase of a penetration test. The tool functions by crawling through the target website and finding various resources such as HTML links, forms, scripts, and other accessible URLs that could potentially lead to vulnerabilities. It also discovers URLs in response content, allowing for a comprehensive link enumeration.



Some of the core functionalities of hakrawler include:


    
    
  • Link Crawling: The tool crawls through a website and collects all the links found on the pages, including internal and external URLs.
    • 
    
  • Form Discovery: hakrawler can identify form elements (e.g., login, search, etc.) within the crawled content, which are important for assessing security risks such as input validation and CSRF vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • JavaScript Link Extraction: The tool can also parse JavaScript content to extract URLs that may not be immediately visible in the HTML source.
    • 
    
  • Customizable Depth: Users can set the depth of crawling, allowing for controlled crawling of the website and focusing on specific sections or levels of the site.
    • 
    
  • Subdomain Discovery: By crawling the base domain and its subdomains, hakrawler can help identify hidden or unindexed pages, making it an excellent tool for surface area discovery during security assessments.
    • 
    
  • Handling Redirects: hakrawler handles HTTP redirects automatically and discovers links that might lead to additional attack surfaces.
    • 




Key Features of hakrawler


    
    
  • Fast Crawling: hakrawler is designed for speed, making it an efficient tool to enumerate links and resources on websites quickly, even on large or complex websites.
    • 
    
  • URL Filtering: The tool supports filtering URLs based on user-defined patterns, enabling researchers to focus on specific types of URLs (e.g., only those that contain `/admin` or `/login`).
    • 
    
  • Flexible Output: hakrawler provides output in different formats, including plain text and JSON, making it easy to analyze or integrate with other tools.
    • 
    
  • Comprehensive Link Discovery: It can find all types of links, including direct HTML links, JavaScript-generated links, and hidden form submissions, which helps discover all potential attack vectors.
    • 
    
  • Recursive Crawling: hakrawler can perform recursive crawling to explore subdirectories and deeper levels within a website.
    • 
    
  • Support for URL Parameters: The tool can identify and enumerate URLs that include query parameters, which could be susceptible to injection attacks or other security vulnerabilities.
    • 




Use Cases


hakrawler is widely used in web application security assessments and penetration testing due to its ability to quickly discover valuable URLs and resources. Some of the primary use cases include:


    
    
  • Web Application Reconnaissance: hakrawler helps security professionals conduct a comprehensive survey of a target website’s accessible links, making it easier to identify areas for further testing.
    • 
    
  • Subdomain and Endpoint Discovery: By crawling a website and its subdomains, hakrawler uncovers hidden pages and endpoints that could expose vulnerabilities, such as sensitive information or improperly secured resources.
    • 
    
  • Form and Input Discovery: Identifying forms and inputs on a website is crucial for security assessments. hakrawler automatically detects form elements, which are valuable for testing input validation, CSRF vulnerabilities, and other attack vectors.
    • 
    
  • JavaScript URL Parsing: Many modern websites rely on JavaScript for dynamic content loading. hakrawler extracts URLs embedded in JavaScript, which may be missed by traditional crawlers.
    • 
    
  • Quick URL Enumeration: In bug bounty programs or red teaming exercises, hakrawler is useful for quickly generating a list of URLs that might expose sensitive or vulnerable endpoints.
    • 




Basic Usage


Here are some basic usage examples for hakrawler:



Basic website crawling:


hakrawler example.com



This command crawls example.com and outputs all discovered URLs in plain text format.



Save discovered URLs to a file:


hakrawler example.com -o urls.txt



This command crawls example.com and saves all discovered URLs to a file named urls.txt.



Output in JSON format:


hakrawler example.com -json



This command retrieves all URLs for example.com and outputs them in JSON format, which can be processed further or imported into other tools for analysis.



Set crawling depth:


hakrawler example.com -d 2



This command limits the crawling depth to 2, which will restrict the tool to crawling up to two levels deep within the website. This is useful for targeting specific sections of a site.



Filter discovered URLs based on pattern:


hakrawler example.com | grep "/admin"



This command crawls example.com and filters the URLs to only show those containing the "/admin" path, which may be important for security testing.



Perform recursive crawling:


hakrawler example.com -r



This command enables recursive crawling, which explores deeper levels of the website to discover hidden pages or resources.



Advanced Usage


hakrawler provides advanced options for users who need more flexibility during crawling:


    
    
  • Custom User-Agent: You can specify a custom User-Agent string using the -ua flag, which is useful for simulating different browser behaviors or bypassing protections that block crawlers.
    • 
    
  • Limit Crawling to Specific Paths: By using the -p flag, you can restrict crawling to specific URL patterns or paths, such as `/admin` or `/login`, for targeted vulnerability testing.
    • 
    
  • Exclusion Filters: You can exclude certain URLs from the results by using the -x flag to define patterns that should not be crawled or reported.
    • 
    
  • Rate Limiting: Use the -r option to control the rate of crawling requests, helping to avoid overwhelming the target server or triggering rate-limiting mechanisms.
    • 
    
  • Parallel Crawling: hakrawler supports parallel crawling, which can speed up the discovery process by querying multiple URLs simultaneously.
    • 



    
    


  
    Basic Crawl
    Crawl with Custom User-Agent
    Include Subdomains
    Save URLs to File
    Exclude Specific Paths
    Limit Depth of Crawl
    Filter for Specific Content
    Verbose Output
    Help

    
    
      
        hakrawler -u https://example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        hakrawler -u https://example.com -A "Mozilla/5.0"
      
      
    

    
      
        hakrawler -u https://example.com --subdomains
      
      
    

    
      
        hakrawler -u https://example.com -o output.txt
      
      
    

    
      
        hakrawler -u https://example.com --exclude "/login"
      
      
    

    
      
        hakrawler -u https://example.com -d 2
      
      
    

    
      
        hakrawler -u https://example.com --filter ".pdf"
      
      
    

    
      
        hakrawler -u https://example.com -v
      
      
    

    
    
      
        Hakrawler Official Documentation
      
      
    
  







    
		
waybackurls Tool


waybackurls is a simple and powerful tool used to gather historical URLs from the Internet Archive's Wayback Machine. It helps security researchers, bug bounty hunters, and penetration testers find previously archived URLs for a target website. This is useful for discovering older, potentially vulnerable pages that may have been removed or hidden from the live site but are still accessible via the Wayback Machine.



What does waybackurls do?


waybackurls queries the Wayback Machine API to retrieve a list of archived URLs for a specific domain. It is often used during the reconnaissance phase of penetration testing or bug bounty hunting to discover old or forgotten URLs that could be overlooked. This includes pages, endpoints, and assets that might be outdated, unpatched, or exposed in past versions of the website.



The tool is especially valuable for discovering:


    
    
  • Old versions of websites: Archived pages that may contain outdated code, misconfigurations, or vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • Deleted or hidden pages: URLs that were once live but are no longer visible on the current website.
    • 
    
  • Assets: Links to scripts, images, or other resources that may be outdated or improperly secured.
    • 
    
  • Sensitive information: Any data accidentally exposed in old versions of the website that can still be accessed via archived URLs.
    • 




Key Features of waybackurls


    
    
  • Fast and Simple: waybackurls is lightweight and quick to use. It leverages the Wayback Machine's vast archive of web pages to search for historical URLs with minimal setup.
    • 
    
  • Support for Custom User-Agent: You can use a custom User-Agent string to control how the tool interacts with the Wayback Machine, potentially bypassing rate-limiting or other restrictions.
    • 
    
  • Efficient Output: The tool outputs the list of URLs in a clean and usable format, making it easy to integrate with other tools for further analysis or testing.
    • 
    
  • Retrieve URLs from Multiple Time Points: You can retrieve URLs from different snapshots of the website, allowing you to view how the site has changed over time.
    • 
    
  • Simple Integration: waybackurls can be easily integrated into other reconnaissance workflows, providing valuable URL data to security researchers and penetration testers.
    • 




Use Cases


waybackurls is commonly used in a variety of security testing scenarios, including:


    
    
  • Historical Vulnerability Discovery: By reviewing older versions of a website, security researchers can identify vulnerabilities that were present in previous iterations of the site but have since been patched or mitigated in newer versions.
    • 
    
  • Finding Sensitive Information: Archived pages may contain sensitive data such as API keys, credentials, or internal documentation that has been accidentally exposed.
    • 
    
  • Subdomain and Path Discovery: Archived URLs can reveal previously unknown subdomains or paths that might not be accessible in the current live version of the website.
    • 
    
  • Retrieving Deleted or Hidden Pages: If a page was removed or hidden, it may still be accessible through the Wayback Machine. This can help uncover previously unreported vulnerabilities or attack surfaces.
    • 
    
  • Reconnaissance in Bug Bounty Programs: Bug bounty hunters can use waybackurls to find old versions of a target website, which might reveal vulnerabilities that were missed or not reported in the current live version.
    • 




Basic Usage


Here are some basic usage examples for the waybackurls tool:



Retrieve URLs for a target domain:


waybackurls example.com



This command queries the Wayback Machine for all archived URLs related to example.com and outputs them in a simple list.



Save discovered URLs to a file:


waybackurls example.com > urls.txt



This command fetches all historical URLs for example.com and saves them to a file named urls.txt for further analysis or processing.



Use with multiple domains from a file:


cat domains.txt | waybackurls



This command reads a list of domains from the domains.txt file and fetches archived URLs for each domain, outputting the results consecutively.



Filter and search for specific URLs:


waybackurls example.com | grep "/admin"



This command retrieves the archived URLs for example.com and filters the results to only show those that include the "/admin" path, which is often a sensitive area of a website.



Advanced Usage


waybackurls provides additional options to customize the output and functionality:


    
    
  • Use a custom User-Agent: To use a custom User-Agent, specify the -u flag:
    
        waybackurls example.com -u "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64)"
    
    • 
    
  • Filter out duplicate URLs: By using -unique, you can eliminate duplicate entries in the output:
    
        waybackurls example.com -unique
    
    • 
    
  • Retrieve URLs for a specific date: Use the -date flag to specify a date to retrieve URLs from a snapshot taken at that time:
    
        waybackurls example.com -date "2023-01-01"
    
    • 
    
  • Use a proxy: waybackurls supports using a proxy to route requests. You can set it with the -proxy flag:
    
        waybackurls example.com -proxy http://127.0.0.1:8080
    
    • 




Conclusion


waybackurls is a useful tool for anyone involved in web application security assessments. By providing easy access to historical URLs archived by the Wayback Machine, it helps uncover potentially vulnerable pages, hidden resources, and sensitive information that may have been removed from the current version of a website. Whether you are performing reconnaissance during a penetration test, bug bounty hunting, or investigating old versions of a website, waybackurls is a valuable addition to your security toolbox.


    
    
 

  
    Basic Wayback URL Search
    Search with Custom User-Agent
    Filter URLs by Regex
    Save Results to File
    Limit Number of Results
    Verbose Output
    Help

    
    
      
        waybackurls https://example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        waybackurls https://example.com -u "Mozilla/5.0"
      
      
    

    
      
        waybackurls https://example.com | grep -P ".*login.*"
      
      
    

    
      
        waybackurls https://example.com -o output.txt
      
      
    

    
      
        waybackurls https://example.com -n 100
      
      
    

    
      
        waybackurls https://example.com -v
      
      
    

    
    
      
        Waybackurls Official Documentation
      
      
    
  







    
		
katana Tool


katana is a modern, fast, and highly customizable tool used for web crawling and reconnaissance. It is designed for security researchers, penetration testers, and bug bounty hunters to gather valuable information about websites, including endpoints, subdomains, and vulnerabilities. katana integrates several web enumeration and reconnaissance tasks into a unified tool, providing a streamlined process for discovering hidden and exposed resources on a target website.



What does katana do?


katana is an active reconnaissance tool that is used to enumerate a wide variety of web resources. It is capable of performing web crawling to gather information about a target's structure, identifying exposed subdomains, URLs, parameters, and hidden pages. Additionally, katana provides functionality for interacting with APIs, finding resources that could be vulnerable, and uncovering misconfigurations in a website’s infrastructure.



katana’s key capabilities include:


    
    
  • Web Crawling: It crawls web applications to discover paths, URLs, subdomains, parameters, and other web resources.
    • 
    
  • Subdomain Enumeration: The tool can identify subdomains associated with a target domain by performing brute-force enumeration and other techniques.
    • 
    
  • Parameter Enumeration: katana automatically detects and enumerates parameters in URLs, helping identify potentially vulnerable endpoints.
    • 
    
  • API Discovery: It can find API endpoints used by a web application, which can be important for assessing security risks.
    • 
    
  • Directory and File Brute-forcing: By brute-forcing common directories and files, katana identifies exposed resources that might be overlooked.
    • 
    
  • Advanced Filters: katana supports advanced filtering mechanisms to refine the results and focus on specific vulnerabilities or resources of interest.
    • 




Key Features of katana


    
    
  • Multi-threaded Crawling: katana supports concurrent requests for faster crawling and enumeration. This significantly reduces the time required to perform reconnaissance on a large web application.
    • 
    
  • Customizable Payloads: You can configure custom payloads to target specific paths, parameters, or resources relevant to your security assessment.
    • 
    
  • Proxy Support: katana allows you to route traffic through a proxy for anonymity or to bypass restrictions and rate-limiting mechanisms.
    • 
    
  • API Integration: It integrates well with APIs, enabling you to discover API endpoints and assess them for security vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • Real-time Output: The tool provides real-time status updates and results, making it easy to monitor progress and assess findings on the fly.
    • 
    
  • Post-exploitation Integration: katana integrates with post-exploitation frameworks to streamline the process of identifying and exploiting web vulnerabilities.
    • 




Use Cases


katana is commonly used in various security testing scenarios, including:


    
    
  • Web Application Penetration Testing: It is highly effective for discovering hidden endpoints, misconfigured APIs, and vulnerable resources on a web application.
    • 
    
  • Bug Bounty Reconnaissance: Bug bounty hunters use katana to gather intelligence on a target site before submitting reports of discovered vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • Subdomain and Directory Discovery: katana can find exposed subdomains and directories, which are often neglected but may present significant security risks.
    • 
    
  • API Security Testing: API endpoints discovered through katana can be tested for common vulnerabilities such as improper authentication or data leaks.
    • 
    
  • Security Research and Vulnerability Assessment: It is an essential tool for security researchers looking to uncover outdated, misconfigured, or vulnerable resources across the internet.
    • 




Basic Usage


Here are some basic usage examples for the katana tool:



Start a crawl of a target domain:


katana -u http://example.com



This command starts a crawl of the example.com domain to discover URLs, subdomains, and other valuable resources.



Brute-force subdomains for a domain:


katana -u example.com --subdomain-brute



This command runs a subdomain enumeration process for example.com using a predefined list of subdomains to find hidden subdomains.



Brute-force directories and files:


katana -u http://example.com --dir-brute



This command starts a brute-forcing process to discover hidden directories or files on the example.com domain.



Save results to a file:


katana -u http://example.com -o results.txt



This command saves the discovered URLs, subdomains, and other relevant data to a file named results.txt for further analysis.



Use a proxy for crawling:


katana -u http://example.com --proxy http://127.0.0.1:8080



This command configures katana to route all requests through a local proxy, which is useful for anonymity or monitoring traffic.



Advanced Usage


katana provides several advanced options for customizing the tool’s behavior and output:


    
    
  • Custom Payloads: Specify custom payloads to target specific paths or parameters on the website:
    
        katana -u example.com --payloads "admin, login, secret"
    
    • 
    
  • API Discovery: Use the --api flag to focus on discovering API endpoints:
    
        katana -u example.com --api
    
    • 
    
  • Filtering Results: Apply filters to refine results based on specific patterns, such as filtering by status codes or specific file types:
    
        katana -u example.com --filter "200, 403, js"
    
    •
