        cat subdomains.txt | xargs -I % nmap -p80,443 --script http-title % && aquatone -d %
      
      
    

    
    
      
        cat subdomains.txt | xargs -I % nmap -p80,443 --script http-enum % && curl https://dnsdumpster.com/ | grep %
      
      
    

    
    
      
        cat subdomains.txt | xargs -I % nmap -p80,443 --script http-vuln* % && amass enum -d %
      
      
    

    
    
      
        cat subdomains.txt | xargs -I % nmap -p80,443 --script http-title % && waybackurls %
      
      
    

    
    
      
        cat subdomains.txt | xargs -I % nmap -p80,443 --script http-vuln-cve2014-6271 % && shodan search %
      
      
    

    
    
      
        cat subdomains.txt | xargs -I % nmap -p80,443 --script http-enum % && dirsearch -u http://%
      
      
    

    
    
      
        cat subdomains.txt | xargs -I % nmap -p80,443 --script http-title % && xsstrike -u http://%/FUZZ
      
      
    
  











  

  


    
     
Burp Suite Tool


Burp Suite is an integrated platform for performing security testing of web applications. It is widely used by security professionals, penetration testers, and bug bounty hunters to identify vulnerabilities and flaws in web applications. Developed by PortSwigger, Burp Suite combines various tools that support the entire web application testing process, from scanning for vulnerabilities to reporting issues. The suite is known for its user-friendly interface and powerful features, which allow for manual and automated testing of websites and applications.



What Does Burp Suite Do?


Burp Suite provides a variety of tools that assist in web application security testing. Some of its core functionalities include:


    
    
  • Intercepting Proxy: The proxy intercepts HTTP/S traffic between the browser and the target application, allowing testers to view and modify requests and responses in real-time. This is the central component for testing and manipulating web applications.
    • 
    
  • Spider: Burp’s spider tool automatically crawls a web application to discover all of its pages and functionality. This helps testers gain an understanding of the site’s structure and surface area for testing.
    • 
    
  • Scanner: Burp Suite includes an active scanner capable of detecting a wide range of vulnerabilities such as SQL injection, Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), and more. It provides an automated way to perform vulnerability assessments.
    • 
    
  • Intruder: The intruder tool is used for performing automated attacks such as brute force, fuzzing, and parameter manipulation on target applications. It can be used to test for weak passwords, session tokens, and other vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • Repeater: The repeater tool allows testers to manually modify and resend individual HTTP requests. This is helpful for testing specific parameters and conducting more refined tests.
    • 
    
  • Sequencer: This tool analyzes the randomness of session tokens and other generated data to assess how difficult it would be for an attacker to predict or guess them.
    • 
    
  • Decoder: The decoder tool helps testers decode or encode data in various formats such as URL, Base64, and HTML entities. This is useful for decoding obfuscated data that may be used in security attacks.
    • 
    
  • Comparer: The comparer tool helps compare two sets of data side-by-side, making it easier to spot differences, such as changes in HTTP requests and responses.
    • 




Key Features of Burp Suite


    
    
  • Proxy Interception: Burp Suite’s intercepting proxy allows testers to inspect, modify, and forward requests between the browser and the target web application. It is a key feature for manual web application testing and penetration testing.
    • 
    
  • Automated Scanning: The automated scanner in Burp Suite can identify common web application vulnerabilities such as XSS, SQL injection, and more. It reduces the need for manual testing, allowing testers to focus on more complex issues.
    • 
    
  • Web Crawling: The spider tool in Burp Suite automatically maps out the target application’s URLs, parameters, and form submissions, helping identify all parts of the application for security testing.
    • 
    
  • Customizable Attacks: With Burp’s intruder tool, users can configure custom payloads to launch a variety of attacks, from brute force to fuzzing, on specific web application parameters.
    • 
    
  • Session Handling: Burp Suite includes functionality for managing session tokens, allowing users to authenticate with target applications and maintain sessions during testing. This helps in testing authenticated areas of a web application.
    • 
    
  • Detailed Reporting: Burp Suite can generate detailed reports summarizing security findings, making it easier to communicate vulnerabilities to clients or stakeholders.
    • 
    
  • Extensibility: Burp Suite has a powerful API and supports extensions that can be added to extend its functionality. There are many plugins available, which can be found in the Burp Suite App Store.
    • 




Burp Suite Editions


Burp Suite comes in several editions, each catering to different levels of functionality and user needs:


    
    
  • Burp Suite Community: This is the free version of Burp Suite, which offers basic features such as the proxy, spider, and repeater tools. It is suitable for individual penetration testers or hobbyists but lacks the more advanced features like automated scanning.
    • 
    
  • Burp Suite Professional: The paid version of Burp Suite that includes all of the features found in the community edition, along with additional capabilities such as automated vulnerability scanning, the intruder tool, and extended reporting options. It is ideal for professional penetration testers and security researchers.
    • 
    
  • Burp Suite Enterprise: This version is designed for large organizations that need to perform automated security testing at scale. It includes features for running scheduled scans, integrating with CI/CD pipelines, and managing a team of security professionals.
    • 




Basic Usage


Here are a few basic tasks that can be performed with Burp Suite:



Intercepting HTTP Requests:


Burp Suite’s proxy intercepts all HTTP/S traffic, allowing you to inspect and modify the requests and responses in real-time. To enable interception, turn on the "Intercept" feature under the Proxy tab. You can then modify headers, parameters, or other parts of the HTTP request before sending it to the server.



Running an Active Scan:


To run an automated scan on a target application, use Burp Suite’s scanner tool. Right-click on any request in the “Target” tab and select “Scan.” The scanner will then begin identifying common web vulnerabilities on the application.



Brute Force Attack with Intruder:


To perform a brute-force attack on a login form, use the intruder tool. Configure the attack by setting the target, selecting the payload type (such as a list of passwords), and defining the attack positions. The intruder will then begin testing the target with the provided payloads.



Generating a Report:


Once testing is complete, Burp Suite can generate a detailed report of the vulnerabilities found. To generate a report, go to the "Reports" tab and choose from various output formats such as HTML, PDF, or XML.



Advanced Features


Burp Suite offers several advanced features to enhance the testing process:


    
    
  • Burp Suite Extensions: Burp Suite supports extensions that extend its functionality, from adding new scanning capabilities to integrating with third-party tools. The Burp Suite App Store provides a collection of free and paid extensions that users can install.
    • 
    
  • Burp Collaborator: Burp Suite includes a tool called Burp Collaborator, which allows testers to identify out-of-band vulnerabilities, such as Blind XSS and Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF). It can be used to detect vulnerabilities that require external communication, such as callbacks to a remote server.
    • 
    
  • Automated Web Application Scanning: Burp Suite’s scanner can detect various vulnerabilities like Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), SQL Injection, and other security flaws. It uses both active and passive scanning techniques to thoroughly assess web applications.
    • 




  



  

  






ffuf Tool


ffuf (Fuzz Faster U Fool) is a fast and flexible web fuzzing tool used by security professionals and penetration testers to discover hidden resources and vulnerabilities in web applications. It is written in Go, making it lightweight, fast, and easy to use for web application fuzzing tasks. ffuf is primarily used for directory and file brute-forcing, but it can be applied to a wide range of fuzzing operations.



What Does ffuf Do?


ffuf is designed to be used for fuzzing various parts of web applications. Its primary usage involves discovering hidden endpoints, directories, and files on a target web server by brute-forcing common names or customized wordlists. Some of its key functionalities include:


    
    
  • Directory and File Fuzzing: ffuf is mainly used to find directories and files that are not publicly listed on a web server. By providing a wordlist, ffuf can automate the process of checking for the existence of resources like admin panels, configuration files, or backup directories.
    • 
    
  • Virtual Host Discovery: ffuf can be used to discover virtual hosts on a web server. It can fuzz subdomains or alternate domains in order to detect hidden services and applications.
    • 
    
  • Content Fuzzing: ffuf can be used to fuzz specific parameters, form fields, and other user inputs for potential vulnerabilities such as SQL injection, XSS, and more.
    • 
    
  • Response Filtering: ffuf can filter responses based on HTTP status codes, size, and other criteria, which allows users to focus on discovering valuable resources or vulnerabilities in web applications.
    • 




Key Features of ffuf


    
    
  • Fast Performance: ffuf is optimized for speed, and its multi-threading capabilities make it faster than many other web fuzzing tools, enabling users to fuzz large target ranges efficiently.
    • 
    
  • Customizable Wordlists: Users can supply their own wordlists or use common pre-built ones for fuzzing various endpoints and resources.
    • 
    
  • HTTP Headers Support: ffuf allows users to add custom HTTP headers for each request, making it useful for testing web applications with specific session or authentication requirements.
    • 
    
  • Response Filtering: Users can filter responses based on various parameters such as status code, response size, or even regex matches. This feature helps in identifying valid responses from invalid ones quickly.
    • 
    
  • Flexible Output Formats: ffuf can generate output in different formats, including plain text, JSON, or even custom formats, providing flexibility for reporting and further analysis.
    • 
    
  • HTTPS Support: ffuf supports fuzzing over HTTPS, allowing penetration testers to check secure websites and web services.
    • 




Common Use Cases


ffuf is widely used for various web application testing tasks, including:


    
    
  • Directory and File Discovery: ffuf is commonly used to discover hidden directories, files, and endpoints on a web server by brute-forcing paths using a wordlist.
    • 
    
  • Subdomain Enumeration: By fuzzing domain names and subdomains, ffuf can uncover hidden web applications and services running on different virtual hosts.
    • 
    
  • Vulnerability Testing: Security testers use ffuf to perform fuzzing attacks on web application input points, such as form fields or parameters, to identify vulnerabilities like SQL injection, XSS, and command injection.
    • 
    
  • Web Application Testing: ffuf is used to quickly explore the structure of a web application, discovering all publicly accessible resources as well as hidden endpoints.
    • 




Basic Usage


Here are a few basic tasks that can be performed with ffuf:



Brute-Forcing Directories and Files:


The most common use case for ffuf is directory and file discovery. To brute-force directories or files, provide a target URL and a wordlist:


ffuf -u http://example.com/FUZZ -w /path/to/wordlist.txt


ffuf will replace the "FUZZ" keyword in the URL with each word in the wordlist, checking for valid responses. You can further filter by status codes, response size, or other parameters.



Filtering Responses by Status Code:


To only show responses with a specific status code (for example, 200 OK), you can use the `-mc` option:


ffuf -u http://example.com/FUZZ -w /path/to/wordlist.txt -mc 200


This command will only show results where the response status code is 200, helping focus on valid results.



Brute-Forcing Subdomains:


ffuf can also be used for subdomain enumeration by fuzzing the domain:


ffuf -u https://FUZZ.example.com -w /path/to/subdomains.txt


This will test subdomains based on the entries in the provided wordlist.



Content Fuzzing:


If you're testing a specific input parameter, such as a form field, use ffuf to send various payloads and check for vulnerabilities:


ffuf -u http://example.com/login -d "username=FUZZ&password=test" -w /path/to/payloads.txt


Here, ffuf will replace "FUZZ" with each word from the wordlist and test for responses.



Advanced Features


ffuf includes several advanced features to enhance fuzzing tasks:


    
    
  • Fuzzing Multiple Parameters: ffuf allows fuzzing multiple parameters at once by using the `-F` option, making it more efficient for complex testing.
    • 
    
  • Recursive Fuzzing: You can enable recursive fuzzing to automatically follow links found during directory fuzzing, expanding the fuzzing scope.
    • 
    
  • Custom HTTP Headers: Use custom headers for requests (e.g., user-agent, authorization) with the `-H` option, which is helpful for authenticated or specific testing scenarios.
    • 
    
  • JSON Output: ffuf can output the results in JSON format for easy processing or integration into other tools and scripts.
    • 




ffuf Options


Some of the commonly used options in ffuf are:


    
    
  • -u: The target URL with "FUZZ" as a placeholder for the wordlist substitution.
    • 
    
  • -w: The path to the wordlist or file to use for fuzzing.
    • 
    
  • -mc: Match responses based on specific status codes, size, or other response parameters.
    • 
    
  • -H: Set custom headers for the HTTP request.
    • 
    
  • -F: Fuzz multiple fields or parameters at once.
    • 
    
  • -o: Save the output to a file for later analysis.
    • 
    
  • -r: Enable recursive fuzzing to follow links.
    • 









  
    Basic Fuzzing
    Fuzzing Parameters
    Fuzzing Headers
    POST Method Fuzzing
    Fuzzing Vhosts
    Help

    
    
      
        ffuf -w wordlist.txt -u https://example.com/FUZZ
      
      
    

    
      
        ffuf -w wordlist.txt -u https://example.com?id=FUZZ
      
      
    

    
      
        ffuf -w wordlist.txt -u https://example.com -H "X-Header: FUZZ"
      
      
    

    
      
        ffuf -w wordlist.txt -u https://example.com -X POST -d "var=FUZZ"
      
      
    

    
      
        ffuf -w vhosts.txt -u https://example.com -H "Host: FUZZ"
      
      
    

    
    
      
        FFUF Official Documentation
      
      
    
  







  

  





getallurls Tool


getallurls is a web scraping and enumeration tool designed to find all URLs associated with a target website. It is particularly useful for security researchers, penetration testers, and bug bounty hunters when performing website enumeration and vulnerability assessments. This tool extracts both visible and hidden URLs from web pages and presents them in an easy-to-read format, helping testers gather a comprehensive list of all the links on a website.



What Does getallurls Do?


getallurls helps in identifying URLs from various parts of a website, which may include:


    
    
  • Links in HTML: It extracts all hyperlinks found within the HTML source code of a website.
    • 
    
  • JavaScript-Generated URLs: The tool also identifies URLs that are dynamically generated by JavaScript, which may not be visible in the raw HTML but are included when the page is loaded in a browser.
    • 
    
  • Redirects and Subdomains: It can identify redirected URLs and subdomains, helping in the discovery of hidden parts of a website.
    • 
    
  • Hidden URLs: The tool also helps identify URLs that may not be listed in the visible content but can be discovered through scraping the underlying source code or by checking JavaScript files.
    • 




Key Features of getallurls


    
    
  • Comprehensive URL Enumeration: getallurls can enumerate URLs not only from anchor tags but also from JavaScript, CSS files, and other web resources.
    • 
    
  • Recursive Crawling: The tool supports recursive crawling, meaning it can follow links from the initial page and continue enumerating URLs found within those pages, expanding the scope of URL discovery.
    • 
    
  • Handles JavaScript: getallurls can also detect URLs that are generated through JavaScript, which are not always visible in the static HTML code.
    • 
    
  • Subdomain Discovery: It can identify subdomains linked to the target site, helping security testers discover hidden services that may not be immediately visible.
    • 
    
  • Supports Multiple URL Sources: The tool can extract URLs from a variety of resources, including JavaScript files, HTML files, and meta tags.
    • 
    
  • Efficient and Fast: The tool is designed for speed, making it capable of processing large websites and many URLs quickly.
    • 




Common Use Cases


getallurls is commonly used in the following scenarios:


    
    
  • Website Enumeration: Security researchers use it to enumerate all URLs associated with a website, helping them understand the structure of the website and identify potential attack vectors.
    • 
    
  • Finding Hidden Resources: The tool helps in discovering hidden resources like admin panels, testing endpoints, or other URLs that may not be publicly advertised but could pose security risks.
    • 
    
  • Subdomain Mapping: By identifying subdomains and hidden services, getallurls can uncover important infrastructure that may be vulnerable to attack.
    • 
    
  • Web Scraping: For gathering data from multiple web pages, getallurls can be used as a scraping tool to extract a full list of URLs for further processing or analysis.
    • 




Basic Usage


The basic syntax for running getallurls is straightforward. The tool requires the target URL and can optionally accept parameters for deeper or more specific scanning:



Enumerating URLs from a Website:


To scrape all URLs from a website:


getallurls http://example.com


This command will extract all visible URLs found within the website, including those embedded in HTML elements.



Recursive URL Enumeration:


To recursively extract URLs from the target website (including URLs found on linked pages), use:


getallurls -r http://example.com


This will continue to crawl linked pages and enumerate all URLs from those pages.



Filtering URLs by Keyword:


To filter URLs by specific keywords (for example, to find URLs containing "admin" or "login"), you can use the `-k` option:


getallurls -k admin http://example.com


This command will only display URLs containing the keyword "admin" in their path or query string.



Saving the Output:


You can save the output of the URL enumeration to a file for later analysis:


getallurls -o output.txt http://example.com


This will save the discovered URLs to `output.txt` in the current directory.



Advanced Features


getallurls also includes several advanced features to help users tailor the tool to specific tasks:


    
    
  • Recursive Crawling: By using the `-r` flag, getallurls can automatically crawl pages linked from the initial URL, gathering even more URLs from the website.
    • 
    
  • Keyword Filtering: The `-k` flag allows users to filter URLs by specific keywords, which can be useful when trying to find particular resources like login pages or admin interfaces.
    • 
    
  • Custom Headers: Users can add custom HTTP headers to requests (such as User-Agent or Authorization) with the `-H` option, which can be useful for testing authenticated endpoints or different configurations.
    • 
    
  • Rate Limiting: The tool can throttle requests using the `-t` option to prevent overwhelming the target server or triggering rate limiting defenses.
    • 
    
  • Subdomain Discovery: getallurls can identify and extract subdomains, uncovering hidden services that might not be obvious at first glance.
    • 




getallurls Options


Some of the commonly used options with getallurls include:


    
    
  • -r: Enable recursive crawling to follow links and extract URLs from subsequent pages.
    • 
    
  • -k: Filter URLs by keyword(s), only showing URLs that match the given term(s).
    • 
    
  • -o: Save the output to a file for future reference and analysis.
    • 
    
  • -H: Add custom HTTP headers to requests, such as `User-Agent` or `Authorization` headers.
    • 
    
  • -t: Set the rate limit for requests, helping avoid triggering rate limiting or blocking mechanisms on the target site.
    • 


 






  
    Basic URL Extraction
    Extract JavaScript URLs
    Find URLs from Sitemap
    Extract Links from HTML
    Find Redirects
    Help

    
    
      
        getallurls -u https://example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        getallurls -u https://example.com --js
      
      
    

    
      
        getallurls -u https://example.com --sitemap
      
      
    

    
      
        getallurls -u https://example.com --html
      
      
    

    
      
        getallurls -u https://example.com --redirects
      
      
    

    
    
      
        GetAllUrls Official Documentation
      
      
    
  






  

  

    

    

linkfinder Tool


linkfinder is an open-source tool designed to search for potential hidden URLs or links in JavaScript files. It is widely used by security researchers and penetration testers to discover valuable information, such as API endpoints, hidden resources, and other potentially sensitive links that may be exposed in JavaScript files on web pages.



What Does linkfinder Do?


linkfinder scans JavaScript files for URLs, which are commonly used in modern web applications. These URLs might not be immediately visible in the main HTML source but can be dynamically loaded or embedded in the JavaScript code. By identifying these URLs, security professionals can uncover attack surfaces and additional entry points for vulnerabilities.



Key Features of linkfinder


    
    
  • JavaScript Scanning: linkfinder specifically targets JavaScript files to search for URLs that may be hidden within the code.
    • 
    
  • Dynamic URL Discovery: It is useful for uncovering URLs dynamically loaded or embedded in JavaScript, which is common in modern single-page applications (SPAs) and AJAX-driven websites.
    • 
    
  • Recursive Search: linkfinder can crawl and recursively scan multiple JavaScript files, helping to uncover additional links hidden in complex web applications.
    • 
    
  • API Endpoint Detection: It helps identify potential API endpoints embedded in JavaScript, which can be valuable for further testing, especially for security flaws like Cross-Site Scripting (XSS), injection flaws, or misconfigured CORS settings.
    • 
    
  • Customizable Search: The tool allows users to customize the search pattern, making it flexible for different types of link finding or for specific types of URL patterns.
    • 




Common Use Cases


linkfinder is commonly used in various scenarios, including:


    
    
  • Web Application Security Testing: It helps security researchers discover hidden URLs or endpoints in JavaScript, which could lead to vulnerabilities like unauthorized API access or information leakage.
    • 
    
  • API Discovery: linkfinder is used to find API endpoints embedded in JavaScript, enabling researchers to test for flaws in web services and integrations.
    • 
    
  • Exposing Hidden Resources: It helps uncover resources like login pages, administrative interfaces, or other potentially sensitive URLs that are not listed in the visible HTML content.
    • 
    
  • Bug Bounty Programs: Bug hunters use linkfinder to increase their chances of finding hidden attack surfaces in web applications by targeting JavaScript files.
    • 




Basic Usage


To use linkfinder, simply provide the URL of the target website or specify the JavaScript files that you want to scan:



Scanning a Website:


To scan a website and find URLs in its JavaScript files, use the following command:


linkfinder -i http://example.com


This command will scan the website for linked JavaScript files and search for any URLs within them.



Scanning Local JavaScript Files:


If you have downloaded JavaScript files locally and want to scan them, use:


linkfinder -i /path/to/javascript/files/


This will scan the local JavaScript files and search for any embedded URLs.



Custom URL Pattern:


To search for specific URL patterns (such as API endpoints), you can provide a custom search pattern:


linkfinder -i http://example.com -p 'api/*'


This will search for any URL patterns that match "api/*" in the JavaScript files, allowing for more focused discovery.



Advanced Features


linkfinder comes with a few advanced features that allow you to tailor your search:


    
    
  • Recursive Scanning: Use the `-r` flag to scan JavaScript files found within linked resources or across different parts of the website.
    • 
    
  • Filtering URLs: You can filter the results to find only URLs that meet certain criteria, such as a specific domain or path.
    • 
    
  • Verbose Output: For more detailed information during the scan, use the `-v` flag for verbose output.
    • 
    
  • Exporting Results: The tool allows you to save the discovered URLs to a file using the `-o` flag, which is helpful for further analysis or reporting.
    • 




linkfinder Options


Some of the common options for using linkfinder include:


    
    
  • -i: Input target URL or local path to JavaScript files for scanning.
    • 
    
  • -r: Enable recursive scanning to follow links in discovered JavaScript files.
    • 
    
  • -p: Provide a custom search pattern (e.g., for finding specific types of URLs like API endpoints).
    • 
    
  • -v: Enable verbose output for more detailed information during the scan.
    • 
    
  • -o: Output the discovered URLs to a file for later use.
    • 


   

    
  
  

  
   

  
    Basic Link Extraction
    Recursive Link Finder
    Find Links from JavaScript
    Find Links from HTML
    Save Output to File
    Help

    
    
      
        linkfinder -i https://example.com
      
      
    

    
      
        linkfinder -i https://example.com --recursive
      
      
    

    
      
        linkfinder -i https://example.com --js
      
      
    

    
      
        linkfinder -i https://example.com --html
      
      
    

    
      
        linkfinder -i https://example.com -o output.txt
      
      
    

    
    
      
        LinkFinder Official Documentation
      
      
    
  




  
  





    
		
		
Google Dorks


Google Dorks refer to advanced search queries used with Google search engine to uncover sensitive or hidden information that may be publicly available on the web. These queries, also known as Google hacking, can be used to find files, information, or vulnerabilities in websites and web applications that are unintentionally exposed to the public.



What Are Google Dorks?


Google Dorks are crafted search queries that leverage Google's powerful search operators to find specific information. These operators can help identify exposed data, such as login credentials, source code files, database backups, or vulnerabilities in web applications.


In the context of cybersecurity, Google Dorks are often used by penetration testers, bug bounty hunters, and security researchers to locate vulnerable or misconfigured systems that might contain sensitive data or be open to attacks.



Common Google Dork Operators


Google Dorks rely on special operators that refine searches. Some of the most commonly used Google search operators are:


    
    
  • site: Limits search results to a specific website or domain. For example, site:example.com will search only within the "example.com" domain.
    • 
    
  • inurl: Searches for specific words in the URL. For example, inurl:admin will search for URLs containing the word "admin".
    • 
    
  • intitle: Searches for specific words in the title tag of web pages. For example, intitle:"login" will return pages with the word "login" in the title.
    • 
    
  • filetype: Limits search results to a specific file type, such as PDF, DOCX, or SQL. For example, filetype:pdf "confidential" will search for PDFs that contain the word "confidential".
    • 
    
  • intext: Searches for specific words in the body text of a page. For example, intext:"password" will return pages with the word "password" in the body text.
    • 
    
  • cache: Returns the cached version of a page. For example, cache:example.com will show the cached version of the "example.com" page.
    • 
    
  • link: Finds pages that link to a particular URL. For example, link:example.com will return pages that have links pointing to "example.com".
    • 
    
  • allinurl: Searches for multiple keywords in the URL. For example, allinurl: login password will search for URLs containing both "login" and "password".
    • 
    
  • allintitle: Searches for multiple keywords in the page title. For example, allintitle: "admin login" "password" will return pages where the title contains both "admin login" and "password".
    • 




Common Google Dorks for Information Gathering


Here are some common Google Dorks that can be used to uncover sensitive information on websites:


    
    
  • site: Used to search within a specific website or domain for certain types of files, such as configuration files or directories. Example: site:example.com filetype:sql
    • 
    
  • inurl: Used to search for exposed web pages or admin panels. Example: inurl:/admin will search for pages with "admin" in the URL.
    • 
    
  • filetype: This can help find specific file types like PDFs, images, or documents that may contain sensitive data. Example: filetype:pdf "confidential"
    • 
    
  • intitle: This operator can be used to search for login pages, error messages, or administration portals by looking for specific words in the page title. Example: intitle:"login"
    • 
    
  • intext: Searches for specific words or phrases in the body text of web pages, which can be useful for finding exposed passwords or other sensitive data. Example: intext:"password"
    • 
    
  • filetype:log: This dork can help in discovering log files that might contain valuable data. Example: filetype:log "error"
    • 




How Google Dorks Are Used in Security Research


Google Dorks are an essential tool for security researchers when performing open-source intelligence (OSINT) gathering. Here’s how they can be used in security testing:


    
    
  • Vulnerability Discovery: Google Dorks can help identify vulnerable files, exposed configurations, or misconfigurations in web applications, such as open database backups or unsecured admin interfaces.
    • 
    
  • Subdomain Enumeration: By searching for exposed subdomains or DNS records, Google Dorks can help discover hidden resources and services associated with a target organization.
    • 
    
  • File Exposure: Security researchers use Google Dorks to find publicly exposed files like logs, backups, or sensitive documents that should not be accessible via the internet.
    • 
    
  • Information Disclosure: Dorks can uncover accidentally disclosed sensitive information, such as login credentials or personal information, which could lead to further exploitation.
    • 
    
  • Social Engineering: Google Dorks can be used to gather data for social engineering attacks by uncovering email addresses, names, or other personal information that may be exposed on a website.
    • 




Ethical Use of Google Dorks


While Google Dorks can be a powerful tool for security research, it is important to use them ethically and responsibly. Security researchers should avoid using Dorks to exploit systems without proper authorization. Many organizations provide legal channels for responsible vulnerability reporting, and it is crucial to follow the legal and ethical guidelines when conducting any security testing.



Examples of Google Dork Queries


Here are some example queries to illustrate how Google Dorks can be used for various purposes:


    
    
  • Find vulnerable admin panels: inurl:/admin
    • 
    
  • Find exposed log files: filetype:log intext:"error"
    • 
    
  • Search for publicly exposed documents: filetype:pdf "confidential"
    • 
    
  • Find a specific type of database: inurl:phpmyadmin filetype:sql
    • 
    
  • Search for exposed backup files: filetype:bak inurl:backup
    • 



    
    
    

		
		



  
    Find Admin Panel
    Find Login Pages
    Find Sensitive Files
    Find File Directories
    Find PHP Files
    Find Email Addresses
    Find Vulnerable Devices
    Find Configuration Files
    Find Backup Files
    Find Login Error Messages
    Help

    
    
      
        site:example.com inurl:admin
      
      
    

    
      
        site:example.com inurl:login
      
      
    

    
      
        site:example.com filetype:pdf
      
      
    

    
      
        site:example.com intitle:"Index of" inurl:ftp
      
      
    

    
      
        site:example.com filetype:php
      
      
    

    
      
        site:example.com inurl:"@gmail.com"
      
      
    

    
      
        site:example.com inurl:"camera" OR inurl:"IP camera"
      
      
    

    
      
        site:example.com inurl:"config" filetype:ini
      
      
    

    
      
        site:example.com filetype:bak
      
      
    

    
      
        site:example.com inurl:"error" intitle:"login"
      
      
    

    
    
      
        Google Dorks Official Documentation
      
      
    
  








    





    
		
		
Arjun Tool


Arjun is an open-source tool designed for automated HTTP parameter discovery. It helps security researchers and penetration testers identify hidden parameters in URLs and HTTP requests that may not be visible at first glance. Arjun can be used to find additional parameters that could lead to vulnerabilities such as injection flaws, information leakage, or privilege escalation.



What is Arjun Tool?


Arjun is an HTTP parameter discovery tool that attempts to identify hidden or forgotten parameters in web applications. By sending multiple HTTP requests with varying combinations of parameters, Arjun helps uncover additional parameters that may be overlooked by the application developers or security testers.


When an attacker or security researcher is trying to discover vulnerabilities in a web application, it's crucial to identify all the parameters that the application uses in its HTTP requests. These parameters may be used for various functions like authentication, data submission, and filtering, and could potentially be misused or exploited if not properly secured.



Key Features of Arjun Tool


    
    
  • Automatic HTTP Request Fuzzing: Arjun automatically sends fuzzed HTTP requests to discover hidden parameters that might not be visible in the application’s initial requests.
    • 
    
  • Efficient Parameter Discovery: The tool tries different combinations of parameter names and values to efficiently find new and hidden parameters.
    • 
    
  • Support for Multiple HTTP Methods: Arjun can handle various HTTP methods such as GET, POST, PUT, and DELETE to explore different types of requests made by the web application.
    • 
    
  • Detailed Output: Arjun provides detailed results about each discovered parameter, including their names and possible vulnerabilities associated with them.
    • 
    
  • Customizable: Arjun allows customization in terms of wordlists, request headers, and specific parameters to focus on during the fuzzing process.
    • 




How Arjun Works


Arjun operates by sending HTTP requests with a set of parameters, some of which are likely to be hidden or not explicitly mentioned in the web application’s interface. It uses predefined wordlists that contain common HTTP parameter names, and it sends these requests to the target web application to find parameters that the application responds to.


The process involves:


    
    
  • Arjun starts by sending a series of HTTP requests to the target with common parameter names.
    • 
    
  • It then waits for responses to determine which parameters are being used and identifies any valid responses.
    • 
    
  • If a parameter leads to a different response, it is added to the list of discovered parameters.
    • 
    
  • The tool then generates a report with all the identified parameters and their characteristics.
    • 




Common Use Cases of Arjun Tool


Arjun is primarily used for the following tasks:


    
    
  • Parameter Discovery: Finding hidden or undocumented parameters that can be leveraged for further testing or exploitation.
    • 
    
  • Web Application Penetration Testing: Used by penetration testers to uncover possible attack surfaces that are not initially visible in a web application.
    • 
    
  • Fuzzing: Arjun can be used as part of a fuzzing strategy to explore a large number of parameter combinations in a web application.
    • 
    
  • Security Audits: Identifying parameters that might lead to vulnerabilities like SQL injection, XSS, or other injection attacks.
    • 




Examples of Using Arjun


Here are some common commands to use Arjun for discovering parameters:


    
    
  • Basic Usage: arjun -u http://example.com - This command will start Arjun’s parameter discovery process on the provided URL.
    • 
    
  • Specifying an HTTP Method: arjun -u http://example.com/login -m POST - This sends POST requests to the target URL to discover parameters that are submitted via POST.
    • 
    
  • Using a Custom Wordlist: arjun -u http://example.com -w /path/to/wordlist.txt - This command uses a custom wordlist for parameter discovery.
    • 
    
  • Handling Headers: arjun -u http://example.com -H "User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0" - This allows you to send custom headers along with the requests to mimic real-world conditions.
    • 




Why Use Arjun?


Arjun is a highly useful tool in a security researcher’s toolkit because it automates the often tedious process of parameter discovery. With Arjun, users can:


    
    
  • Quickly discover hidden or forgotten parameters without manually inspecting every part of the web application.
    • 
    
  • Perform more comprehensive penetration testing by exploring all possible input vectors within the application.
    • 
    
  • Improve security audits by finding parameters that could be misused or poorly secured.
    • 




Ethical Considerations


As with all security tools, Arjun should only be used for ethical purposes. Always ensure that you have explicit permission to test a web application or website. Unauthorized testing or attacking systems can be illegal and unethical. Always follow legal guidelines and the responsible disclosure process when identifying vulnerabilities in a system.


    
    
    

		
		

  
    Basic Parameter Discovery
    Specify HTTP Method
    Use Custom Wordlist
    Filter by Status Codes
    Change Number of Threads
    Output to File
    Set Timeout
    Scan HTTPS URLs
    Proxy Support
    Help

    
    
      
        arjun -u https://example.com
      
      
    

    
    
      
        arjun -u https://example.com -m POST
      
      
    

    
    
      
        arjun -u https://example.com -w /path/to/wordlist.txt
      
      
    

    
    
      
        arjun -u https://example.com --include-codes 200,301
      
      
    

    
    
      
        arjun -u https://example.com -t 10
      
      
    

    
    
      
        arjun -u https://example.com -o output.json
      
      
    

    
    
      
        arjun -u https://example.com --timeout 5
      
      
    

    
    
      
        arjun -u https://example.com --https
      
      
    

    
    
      
        arjun -u https://example.com --proxy http://127.0.0.1:8080
      
      
    

    
    
      
        Arjun Official Documentation
      
      
    
  



    





    
		
Dirsearch Tool


Dirsearch is a simple yet powerful open-source command-line tool used for directory and file brute-forcing in web servers. It helps security researchers, penetration testers, and bug bounty hunters identify hidden files and directories that might not be directly accessible or indexed by the web server. These hidden paths can sometimes expose sensitive information or serve as entry points for exploitation.



What is Dirsearch?


Dirsearch is a Python-based tool designed to automate the process of discovering directories and files on web servers. By sending a large number of HTTP requests using wordlists, Dirsearch can uncover hidden or unlinked resources that are not visible in the website's main interface. These resources might include configuration files, admin panels, backup files, or other sensitive data.



Key Features of Dirsearch


    
    
  • Customizable Wordlists: Dirsearch allows users to use their own wordlists for targeted brute-forcing based on the application being tested.
    • 
    
  • Supports Multiple Protocols: The tool works with HTTP, HTTPS, and other protocols to cover a wide range of web applications.
    • 
    
  • Concurrency and Performance: Dirsearch is designed for high-speed brute-forcing using multithreading, allowing users to scan large lists efficiently.
    • 
    
  • Custom HTTP Methods: Users can specify HTTP methods like GET, POST, PUT, and others to test different scenarios.
    • 
    
  • Extension Filters: It allows filtering results by file extensions, such as `.php`, `.html`, `.txt`, or even custom extensions.
    • 
    
  • Proxy Support: Dirsearch can be configured to route traffic through proxies for anonymity or bypassing restrictions.
    • 
    
  • Recursive Scanning: The tool supports recursive scans, meaning it can explore directories discovered during the initial scan.
    • 
    
  • Custom Headers: Users can include custom HTTP headers for more realistic testing or bypassing certain restrictions.
    • 




How Dirsearch Works


Dirsearch works by sending HTTP requests to the target web server using words from a predefined or custom wordlist. Each word is appended to the base URL as a directory or file name. The tool observes the server's responses to determine whether the requested resource exists. Successful responses (e.g., HTTP 200 or 301 status codes) indicate the presence of the directory or file.



Common Use Cases of Dirsearch


    
    
  • Discovering Hidden Resources: Identify unlinked directories and files that might contain sensitive information or functionality.
    • 
    
  • Web Application Penetration Testing: Test for exposed admin panels, configuration files, or other sensitive areas of the application.
    • 
    
  • Vulnerability Assessments: Find backup files, outdated scripts, or misconfigured resources that could lead to vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • Bug Bounty Hunting: Use Dirsearch to locate hidden endpoints in web applications that could be exploited for bounties.
    • 




Examples of Using Dirsearch


Here are some common Dirsearch commands:


    
    
  • Basic Usage: python3 dirsearch.py -u http://example.com - Scans the target URL with the default wordlist.
    • 
    
  • Specify a Custom Wordlist: python3 dirsearch.py -u http://example.com -w /path/to/wordlist.txt - Uses a custom wordlist for the scan.
    • 
    
  • Scan for Specific Extensions: python3 dirsearch.py -u http://example.com -e php,html,txt - Focuses on files with specified extensions.
    • 
    
  • Recursive Scanning: python3 dirsearch.py -u http://example.com -r - Enables recursive scanning for discovered directories.
    • 
    
  • Proxy Support: python3 dirsearch.py -u http://example.com --proxy http://127.0.0.1:8080 - Routes traffic through a proxy.
    • 
    
  • Custom Headers: python3 dirsearch.py -u http://example.com -H "User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0" - Adds a custom User-Agent header to the requests.
    • 




Why Use Dirsearch?


Dirsearch is widely used for its simplicity, efficiency, and versatility. It helps security professionals uncover hidden resources that might not be apparent through traditional web application testing. By identifying such resources, researchers can better understand the application's structure and locate potential security issues.



Ethical Considerations


Always ensure you have explicit permission to scan a web server before using Dirsearch. Unauthorized scanning can be illegal and unethical. Use Dirsearch responsibly and in accordance with legal and ethical guidelines.


    
    
    

		
		

  
    Basic Usage
    Custom Wordlist
    Specify Extensions
    Recursive Scan
    Save Output
    Custom User-Agent
    Exclude Status Codes
    Proxy Support
    Threads Control
    Help

    
    
      
        python3 dirsearch.py -u https://example.com
      
      
    

    
    
      
        python3 dirsearch.py -u https://example.com -w /path/to/wordlist.txt
      
      
    

    
    
      
        python3 dirsearch.py -u https://example.com -e php,html,js
      
      
    

    
    
      
        python3 dirsearch.py -u https://example.com --recursive
      
      
    

    
    
      
        python3 dirsearch.py -u https://example.com -o output.txt
      
      
    

    
    
      
        python3 dirsearch.py -u https://example.com --user-agent "CustomUserAgent/1.0"
      
      
    

    
    
      
        python3 dirsearch.py -u https://example.com --exclude-status 403,404
      
      
    

    
    
      
        python3 dirsearch.py -u https://example.com --proxy http://127.0.0.1:8080
      
      
    

    
    
      
        python3 dirsearch.py -u https://example.com -t 20
      
      
    

    
    
      
        Dirsearch Official Documentation
      
      
    
  



    





    
		
		
cURL Tool


cURL (Client URL) is a versatile command-line tool and library used for transferring data to and from servers using various network protocols. It is commonly utilized by developers, system administrators, and security researchers for tasks ranging from debugging and testing APIs to automating data transfers and analyzing web applications. With support for numerous protocols and features, cURL is an essential utility for working with network communication.



What is cURL?


cURL is an open-source tool designed to facilitate data transfers over network protocols such as HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, SFTP, SMTP, and more. It enables users to interact with web servers by crafting custom requests, sending payloads, retrieving responses, and inspecting server behavior. It can be used in scripts or directly from the command line.



Key Features of cURL


    
    
  • Protocol Support: Works with a wide range of protocols, including HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, SFTP, SMTP, IMAP, and more.
    • 
    
  • Custom HTTP Methods: Supports GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, HEAD, and other HTTP methods for API interaction.
    • 
    
  • Headers and Cookies: Allows adding custom headers, cookies, and other parameters to HTTP requests.
    • 
    
  • File Uploads and Downloads: Facilitates secure file transfers using supported protocols.
    • 
    
  • Authentication Support: Includes basic, digest, NTLM, and token-based authentication options.
    • 
    
  • Proxy Support: Routes traffic through HTTP, SOCKS, or other proxies.
    • 
    
  • Data Formatting: Can handle JSON, XML, and other data formats for request payloads and response parsing.
    • 
    
  • SSL/TLS Support: Enables secure communication with support for certificates and key management.
    • 
    
  • Debugging Capabilities: Provides detailed request and response information for troubleshooting.
    • 




How cURL Works


cURL sends network requests to servers and displays the response. It uses a simple syntax where users specify the URL, HTTP methods, headers, and any required data. The response can be saved to a file, processed in real time, or displayed on the terminal.



Common Use Cases of cURL


    
    
  • API Testing: Test REST APIs by sending custom requests with various methods, headers, and payloads.
    • 
    
  • Web Scraping: Retrieve web content for analysis or data extraction.
    • 
    
  • File Transfers: Upload or download files securely using supported protocols.
    • 
    
  • Server Debugging: Inspect headers, cookies, and responses for troubleshooting server issues.
    • 
    
  • Automation: Automate repetitive tasks like data fetching or API calls using scripts.
    • 




Examples of Using cURL


Here are some common cURL commands:


    
    
  • Basic GET Request: curl http://example.com - Fetches the content of a webpage.
    • 
    
  • Specify Headers: curl -H "User-Agent: CustomAgent" http://example.com - Sends a GET request with a custom User-Agent header.
    • 
    
  • Send POST Data: curl -X POST -d "key=value" http://example.com - Sends a POST request with form data.
    • 
    
  • Save Output to a File: curl -o output.html http://example.com - Saves the response to a file.
    • 
    
  • Follow Redirects: curl -L http://example.com - Follows HTTP redirects to the final destination.
    • 
    
  • Use Authentication: curl -u username:password http://example.com - Sends a request with basic authentication.
    • 
    
  • Inspect Response Headers: curl -I http://example.com - Fetches and displays only the response headers.
    • 
    
  • Proxy Support: curl -x http://proxy:8080 http://example.com - Routes traffic through a proxy server.
    • 




Why Use cURL?


cURL is a lightweight yet powerful tool that provides comprehensive capabilities for interacting with servers and analyzing network traffic. Its flexibility and extensive protocol support make it indispensable for various use cases, from testing APIs to debugging and automating workflows in both development and security contexts.



Ethical Considerations


Always ensure you have appropriate permissions before using cURL for tasks like web scraping or network analysis. Unethical or unauthorized use can lead to legal consequences or disrupt services.


    
    
    

		


  
    Intro
    GET Requests
    POST Requests
    HEAD Requests
    Authentication
    Help

    
    
      
        

          cURL is a powerful command-line tool for transferring data using various protocols like HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, and more. It is widely used for testing and debugging web applications.
        

      
    

    
    
      
        curl https://example.com
      
      
    

    
    
      
        curl -X POST -d "key=value" https://example.com
      
      
    

    
    
      
        curl -I https://example.com
      
      
    

    
    
      
        curl -u username:password https://example.com
      
      
    

    
    
      
        cURL Official Documentation
      
      
    
  






    





    
		
		
Wfuzz Tool


Wfuzz is a powerful command-line web application brute-forcer used by penetration testers and security researchers to identify vulnerabilities in web applications. It excels at fuzzing parameters, directories, files, and other inputs to uncover security weaknesses such as hidden endpoints, SQL injection points, or XSS vulnerabilities.



What is Wfuzz?


Wfuzz is a flexible and extensible tool designed for web application fuzzing. It automates the process of sending payloads to specific parts of a web application and analyzing responses to detect anomalies or vulnerabilities. The tool supports a wide range of customization options, making it ideal for complex and targeted assessments.



Key Features of Wfuzz


    
    
  • Flexible Payloads: Supports multiple payload types, including wordlists, ranges, and custom patterns.
    • 
    
  • Parameter Fuzzing: Identifies vulnerabilities in GET and POST parameters.
    • 
    
  • Directory and File Brute-forcing: Discovers hidden files and directories within web servers.
    • 
    
  • Customizable Requests: Allows users to craft HTTP requests with custom headers, cookies, and methods.
    • 
    
  • Response Filtering: Filters results based on HTTP status codes, response size, or keywords.
    • 
    
  • Proxy Support: Routes traffic through HTTP or SOCKS proxies for advanced testing scenarios.
    • 
    
  • Authentication: Supports basic, digest, and token-based authentication.
    • 
    
  • Multithreading: Increases efficiency by sending multiple requests simultaneously.
    • 
    
  • Custom Output: Formats output to suit user preferences, including JSON or plaintext.
    • 




How Wfuzz Works


Wfuzz operates by replacing a placeholder keyword (typically FUZZ) in HTTP requests with payloads from a user-defined source, such as a wordlist or range. It sends these requests to the target web application and analyzes the responses for patterns, anomalies, or other indications of vulnerabilities.



Common Use Cases of Wfuzz


    
    
  • Endpoint Discovery: Brute-forces directories and files to find hidden endpoints.
    • 
    
  • Parameter Testing: Identifies vulnerable parameters in GET or POST requests.
    • 
    
  • Injection Testing: Tests for SQL injection, XSS, or command injection vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • Authentication Testing: Brute-forces login forms or API keys.
    • 
    
  • Custom Fuzzing: Explores unconventional attack surfaces with tailored payloads.
    • 




Examples of Using Wfuzz


Here are some common commands:


    
    
  • Directory Brute-forcing: wfuzz -c -z file,/path/to/wordlist.txt --hc 404 http://example.com/FUZZ - Finds directories by fuzzing the URL path while excluding 404 responses.
    • 
    
  • Parameter Fuzzing: wfuzz -c -z file,/path/to/params.txt -d "param=FUZZ" http://example.com - Tests different payloads in the param parameter of a POST request.
    • 
    
  • Filter by Status Code: wfuzz -c -z file,/path/to/wordlist.txt --sc 200 http://example.com/FUZZ - Displays only responses with a 200 status code.
    • 
    
  • Using Proxies: wfuzz --proxy http://127.0.0.1:8080 -c -z file,/path/to/wordlist.txt http://example.com/FUZZ - Routes traffic through a proxy for monitoring or bypassing restrictions.
    • 
    
  • Header Fuzzing: wfuzz -c -z file,/path/to/headers.txt -H "X-Custom-Header: FUZZ" http://example.com - Tests different values in a custom HTTP header.
    • 




Why Use Wfuzz?


Wfuzz is an essential tool for penetration testers due to its ability to uncover hidden vulnerabilities with precision and efficiency. Its flexibility, combined with advanced filtering and output options, makes it suitable for a wide range of security assessments. By providing robust fuzzing capabilities, Wfuzz enables researchers to identify potential weaknesses that could be exploited in real-world scenarios.



Ethical Considerations


Wfuzz should only be used with proper authorization. Unauthorized use of the tool on websites or servers can lead to legal consequences and ethical violations. Always follow responsible disclosure practices and obtain explicit permission before testing.


    
    
    
    

		


  
    Intro
    Basic Fuzzing
    Fuzzing Parameters
    Fuzzing Headers
    Advanced Options
    Help

    
    
      
        

          Wfuzz is a versatile web application security tool used to brute force parameters, headers, and directories to uncover hidden resources or vulnerabilities in websites.
        

      
    

    
    
      
        wfuzz -w /path/to/wordlist -u https://example.com/FUZZ
      
      
    

    
    
      
        wfuzz -w /path/to/wordlist -u https://example.com?id=FUZZ
      
      
    

    
    
      
        wfuzz -w /path/to/wordlist -u https://example.com -H "X-Header: FUZZ"
      
      
    

    
    
      
        wfuzz -c -w /path/to/wordlist -u https://example.com/FUZZ -t 50 --hc 404
      
      
    

    
    
      
        Wfuzz Official Documentation
      
      
    
  





    





    
		
		
Zzuf Tool


Zzuf is a versatile fuzzing tool designed to identify software vulnerabilities by introducing random, controlled modifications to input files or data streams. It is widely used in security testing, particularly for applications that process untrusted input, such as media players, file parsers, or network protocols.



What is Zzuf?


Zzuf is a fuzzing utility that operates by corrupting data streams in a deterministic or random manner. It allows testers to uncover issues such as memory corruption, buffer overflows, and crashes by feeding the mutated input to the target application. Its simplicity and effectiveness make it a popular choice for security researchers and developers looking to test software robustness.



Key Features of Zzuf


    
    
  • Data Stream Corruption: Modifies input data streams to test how applications handle unexpected inputs.
    • 
    
  • Customizable Fuzzing: Allows control over fuzzing parameters such as the corruption rate and seed values for reproducibility.
    • 
    
  • Binary Compatibility: Works with any binary executable or script, making it highly adaptable.
    • 
    
  • Reproducible Results: Generates reproducible mutations by using seed values, enabling consistent testing.
    • 
    
  • Standard I/O Support: Fuzzes inputs from files, pipes, or standard input/output streams.
    • 
    
  • Lightweight and Fast: Minimal setup with efficient mutation capabilities.
    • 




How Zzuf Works


Zzuf intercepts and modifies input data as it is read by an application. It corrupts specific bytes in the data stream based on the user-defined fuzzing parameters. The corrupted data is then processed by the target application, and the tester monitors the application's behavior for crashes, errors, or other anomalies that may indicate vulnerabilities.



Common Use Cases of Zzuf


    
    
  • File Format Testing: Identifies vulnerabilities in applications that parse files such as images, videos, or documents.
    • 
    
  • Protocol Testing: Tests network applications by fuzzing incoming data streams.
    • 
    
  • Robustness Testing: Ensures software can handle unexpected or malformed input gracefully.
    • 
    
  • Regression Testing: Validates that previous vulnerabilities have been fixed by replaying corrupted inputs.
    • 




Examples of Using Zzuf


Here are some common commands:


    
    
  • Basic File Fuzzing: zzuf -r 0.01 -s 42 -o output.txt input.txt - Corrupts a file with a 1% corruption rate and outputs the modified data to output.txt.
    • 
    
  • Pipe Data to an Application: zzuf -r 0.05 -s 100 | ./app - Sends a fuzzed data stream to the application via a pipe.
    • 
    
  • Fuzzing with Specific Seed: zzuf -r 0.02 -s 1234 input.txt - Uses a specific seed value to generate reproducible mutations.
    • 
    
  • Monitor Output: zzuf -r 0.03 -v -s 5678 input.txt | grep "error" - Corrupts input and filters the application’s output for errors.
    • 




Why Use Zzuf?


Zzuf is a valuable tool for uncovering hidden vulnerabilities in software by automating the process of injecting unexpected input. Its ability to produce reproducible results and work seamlessly with various applications makes it an essential component of a security tester's toolkit. By testing edge cases and malformed inputs, Zzuf helps improve software reliability and security.



Ethical Considerations


Zzuf should only be used on systems and applications where you have explicit permission to perform testing. Unauthorized use may lead to ethical breaches and legal consequences. Always adhere to responsible disclosure policies and ethical guidelines when conducting security assessments.


    
    
    

		


  
    Intro
    Basic Fuzzing
    Fuzzing with Output
    Fuzzing Network Applications
    Advanced Options
    Help

    
    
      
        

          zzuf is a fuzzing tool that modifies file inputs or network streams to test software for unexpected behaviors or vulnerabilities. It is effective for testing applications that process structured file formats or network protocols.
        

      
    

    
    
      
        zzuf -r 0.002 -s 42 -i example.txt -o fuzzed_output.txt
      
      
    

    
    
      
        zzuf -r 0.01 -s 100 -o fuzzed_file.txt -- example-program
      
      
    

    
    
      
        zzuf -r 0.002 -s 20 -- nc -l 1234
      
      
    

    
    
      
        zzuf -r 0.005 -b 0.1,0.2 -s 200 -o advanced_output.txt -- ./test-application
      
      
    

    
    
      
        zzuf Official Documentation
      
      
    
  




    





    
		
		
XSStrike Tool


XSStrike is an advanced cross-site scripting (XSS) detection and exploitation tool designed to help security researchers and penetration testers identify and exploit XSS vulnerabilities in web applications. Unlike traditional XSS scanners, XSStrike focuses on intelligent payload generation and bypassing common filters, making it a powerful tool for assessing web application security.



What is XSStrike?


XSStrike is a Python-based tool that automates the process of identifying XSS vulnerabilities. It analyzes input fields, constructs payloads tailored to the target application’s context, and attempts to exploit XSS vulnerabilities. It is capable of bypassing Web Application Firewalls (WAFs) and other filtering mechanisms to provide a thorough assessment of an application's susceptibility to XSS attacks.



Key Features of XSStrike


    
    
  • Payload Generation: Generates context-aware payloads to test different XSS scenarios effectively.
    • 
    
  • WAF Bypassing: Includes techniques to evade common Web Application Firewall protections.
    • 
    
  • Parameter Discovery: Detects parameters and input fields in web applications that are potentially vulnerable.
    • 
    
  • DOM-Based XSS Testing: Supports testing for client-side (DOM-based) XSS vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • Automated Scanning: Automates the process of identifying and exploiting XSS vulnerabilities with minimal manual effort.
    • 
    
  • Flexible Configuration: Allows customization of headers, cookies, and other parameters during scans.
    • 




How XSStrike Works


XSStrike operates by sending crafted payloads to web applications through input fields or URL parameters. It observes the application’s response to determine whether the payload is executed. The tool leverages its built-in payload generator and filter evasion techniques to bypass defenses and identify vulnerabilities effectively.



Common Use Cases of XSStrike


    
    
  • Identifying XSS Vulnerabilities: Tests web applications for stored, reflected, and DOM-based XSS vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • Testing WAFs: Assesses the effectiveness of WAFs and other security mechanisms against XSS attacks.
    • 
    
  • Security Audits: Automates XSS testing during web application penetration testing and security assessments.
    • 




Examples of Using XSStrike


Here are some common commands:


    
    
  • Basic Scan: python3 xsstrike.py -u "http://example.com?search=test" - Scans the provided URL for XSS vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • Custom Headers: python3 xsstrike.py -u "http://example.com" --headers '{"User-Agent": "CustomUserAgent"}' - Uses custom headers during the scan.
    • 
    
  • DOM-Based XSS Testing: python3 xsstrike.py -u "http://example.com" --crawl - Crawls the target application for potential DOM-based XSS vulnerabilities.
    • 
    
  • Bypass WAF: python3 xsstrike.py -u "http://example.com" --skip-waf - Attempts to bypass WAF protections during the scan.
    • 




Why Use XSStrike?


XSStrike is a robust tool for security professionals who need to conduct comprehensive XSS testing. Its ability to bypass WAFs, generate sophisticated payloads, and automate testing makes it invaluable for identifying and exploiting XSS vulnerabilities. Whether you are a beginner or an experienced penetration tester, XSStrike streamlines the XSS testing process and provides insightful results for improving web application security.



Ethical Considerations


Always use XSStrike responsibly and with explicit permission from the application owner. Unauthorized use may lead to legal consequences and ethical violations. Adhere to ethical guidelines and responsible disclosure policies when conducting XSS assessments.


    
    
    

		


  
    Intro
    Basic Scan
    Crawl and Scan
    Fuzz Parameters
    Test Payloads
    Help

    
    
      
        

          XSStrike is an advanced Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) detection suite capable of fuzzing, payload generation, and parameter crawling. It is designed to help identify and exploit XSS vulnerabilities.
        

      
    

    
    
      
        python3 xsstrike.py -u https://example.com
      
      
    

    
    
      
        python3 xsstrike.py -u https://example.com --crawl
      
      
    

    
    
      
        python3 xsstrike.py -u https://example.com --fuzzer
      
      
    

    
    
      
        python3 xsstrike.py -u https://example.com --payloads
      
      
    

    
    
      
        XSStrike Official Documentation
      
      
    
  




    





    
		
		
Corsy Tool


Corsy is a lightweight and efficient tool for detecting misconfigurations in Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) implementations. It is specifically designed to help security researchers and penetration testers identify vulnerabilities that can arise due to improperly configured CORS policies, which may lead to unauthorized access or data exposure.



What is Corsy?


Corsy is a Python-based tool that automates the process of checking web applications for CORS misconfigurations. By analyzing the Access-Control-Allow-Origin and related headers, it determines whether the server allows potentially unsafe cross-origin requests, which could be exploited by attackers to steal sensitive data or escalate privileges.



Key Features of Corsy


    
    
  • Automated Detection: Scans web applications to identify CORS misconfigurations quickly.
    • 
    
  • Header Analysis: Examines CORS-related headers such as Access-Control-Allow-Origin, Access-Control-Allow-Credentials, and Access-Control-Allow-Methods.
    • 
    
  • Custom Requests: Supports crafting custom HTTP requests for testing specific endpoints.
    • 
    
  • Wide Protocol Support: Works with HTTP and HTTPS endpoints.
    • 
    
  • Detailed Reporting: Provides insights into detected vulnerabilities and their potential impact.
    • 




How Corsy Works


Corsy sends specially crafted HTTP requests to the target application and evaluates the responses to identify misconfigurations in CORS headers. It tests whether the application improperly trusts arbitrary origins or allows credentials to be shared with untrusted origins. The tool flags these issues and highlights potential risks.



Common Use Cases of Corsy


    
    
  • Vulnerability Detection: Identifies CORS misconfigurations that could lead to unauthorized data access or privilege escalation.
    • 
    
  • Compliance Testing: Ensures that web applications adhere to secure CORS practices.
    • 
    
  • Security Audits: Automates CORS testing during penetration testing and vulnerability assessments.
    • 




Examples of Using Corsy


Here are some common commands:


    
    
  • Basic Scan: python3 corsy.py -u "http://example.com" - Scans the specified URL for CORS misconfigurations.
    • 
    
  • Scan with Proxy: python3 corsy.py -u "http://example.com" --proxy "http://127.0.0.1:8080" - Routes the scan through a proxy, such as Burp Suite, for advanced interception.
    • 
    
  • Test HTTPS Endpoint: python3 corsy.py -u "https://example.com" - Scans an HTTPS endpoint for CORS issues.
    • 
    
  • Custom Headers: python3 corsy.py -u "http://example.com" --headers '{"Authorization": "Bearer token"}' - Adds custom headers to the scan request.
    • 




Why Use Corsy?


Corsy simplifies the detection of CORS-related vulnerabilities, making it a valuable tool for security professionals and developers. Its ability to automate complex tests, generate detailed reports, and work seamlessly with various endpoints ensures accurate and efficient assessments of web application security. By identifying and addressing CORS misconfigurations, Corsy helps enhance the security posture of web applications.



Ethical Considerations


Always use Corsy on systems where you have explicit permission to conduct security testing. Unauthorized use of the tool may result in legal and ethical consequences. Follow responsible disclosure policies when reporting identified vulnerabilities.


    
    
    

		
		

  
    Intro
    Basic Usage
    Scan URL
    Timeout
    Headers
    Output
    Help

    
    
      
        

          Corsy is a lightweight CORS misconfiguration scanner. It detects potential Cross-Origin Resource Sharing vulnerabilities in web applications.
        

      
    

    
    
      
        python3 corsy.py -u https://example.com
      
      
    

    
    
      
        python3 corsy.py -u https://example.com
      
      
    

    
    
      
        python3 corsy.py -u https://example.com --timeout 15
      
      
    

    
    
      
        python3 corsy.py -u https://example.com -H "Authorization: Bearer token"
      
      
    

    
    
      
        python3 corsy.py -u https://example.com --output results.txt
      
      
    

    
    
      
        Corsy Official Documentation
      
      
    
  



    









  


    
    

  

    
    
    
    
    
    
    
    





  





  


    
    


Shodan Tool


Shodan is a powerful search engine that scans the internet for connected devices and exposes information about them, such as their IP addresses, ports, services, and vulnerabilities. Often referred to as the "Google for hackers," Shodan helps security professionals, researchers, and system administrators discover exposed devices and misconfigurations that may pose a security risk.



What is Shodan?


Shodan is a search engine specifically designed to find internet-connected devices like servers, routers, webcams, IoT devices, and other networked systems. Unlike traditional search engines that index web pages, Shodan indexes metadata about devices and services exposed to the internet. This metadata can include device type, software versions, open ports, and security vulnerabilities, making it a valuable tool for cybersecurity professionals.



Key Features of Shodan


    
    
  • Device Discovery: Identifies internet-connected devices, ranging from servers and databases to IoT devices like cameras and smart thermostats.
    • 
    
  • Security Assessment: Analyzes devices for exposed vulnerabilities, outdated software, and misconfigurations that could be exploited by attackers.
    • 
    
  • Geo-Location: Provides geographic information about the devices, helping to visualize the global distribution of exposed services.
    • 
    
  • Advanced Search Filters: Supports advanced search queries to refine searches by device type, software version, location, and other parameters.
    • 
    
  • API Access: Offers an API that allows users to integrate Shodan’s data into their tools or scripts for automated queries and reporting.
    • 
    
  • Historical Data: Allows access to past data, enabling users to track the presence and changes of devices over time.
    • 




How Shodan Works


Shodan works by continuously scanning the internet for connected devices and services. It gathers metadata from the devices it finds, such as open ports, banners, software versions, and other identifying information. This data is then indexed and made searchable through the Shodan website or API. Users can query this data to identify exposed devices, analyze their configurations, and check for vulnerabilities.



Common Use Cases of Shodan


    
    
  • Vulnerability Scanning: Security professionals use Shodan to identify exposed devices with known vulnerabilities or misconfigurations.
    • 
    
  • IoT Security Assessment: Researchers use Shodan to discover vulnerable IoT devices and assess their security posture.
    • 
    
  • Network Mapping: Shodan can help system administrators map out their network by identifying all exposed devices and services.
    • 
    
  • Incident Response: During a security incident, Shodan can help identify compromised or misconfigured devices across the internet.
    • 




Examples of Using Shodan


Here are some common commands:


    
    
  • Search by Device Type: shodan search "webcam" - Finds internet-connected webcams.
    • 
    
  • Search by Port: shodan search "port:80" - Finds devices with port 80 open.
    • 
    
  • Search by Location: shodan search "country:US" - Finds devices located in the United States.
    • 
    
  • Search for Specific Vulnerabilities: shodan search "vuln:heartbleed" - Finds devices vulnerable to the Heartbleed exploit.
    • 




Why Use Shodan?


Shodan is a valuable tool for cybersecurity professionals and system administrators who need to understand the exposure of their networks and devices. It provides unique insights into how devices are configured and whether they are at risk of exploitation. With its advanced search capabilities and extensive device database, Shodan is an essential tool for identifying vulnerabilities, monitoring IoT security, and mapping out internet-connected infrastructures.



Ethical Considerations


Shodan should be used responsibly and legally. Unauthorized scanning or probing of devices without permission can lead to legal consequences. Always ensure that you have proper authorization before conducting any security assessments. Follow responsible disclosure practices when reporting vulnerabilities discovered using Shodan.


      
  
  




  
    Intro
    Search
    Info
    Ports
    Help

    
    
      
        

          Shodan is a search engine for internet-connected devices. It allows users to search for specific devices, services, and vulnerabilities based on the information exposed online.
        

      
    

    
    
      
        shodan search apache
      
      
    

    
    
      
        shodan host 8.8.8.8
      
      
    

    
    
      
        shodan port 80
      
      
    

    
    
      
        Shodan Official API Documentation
      
      
    
  






  
    HTTP Server Vulnerabilities
    Open Database Servers
    SSL/TLS Misconfigurations
    Webcam Feeds
    FTP Servers
    Outdated Software
    Default Credentials
    Exposed Admin Panels
    Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
    Remote Code Execution (RCE)

    
    
      
        http.title:"example.com" AND vuln
      
      
      
Searches for HTTP servers hosting the specified target and lists known vulnerabilities.

    

    
    
      
        hostname:"example.com" AND port:27017
      
      
      
Identifies open MongoDB servers on the specified target.

    

    
    
      
        ssl.cert.subject.CN:"example.com" AND vuln
      
      
      
Finds SSL/TLS certificates associated with the target and any known vulnerabilities.

    

    
    
      
        http.title:"example.com" AND "webcam"
      
      
      
Looks for open webcam feeds hosted under the target domain.

    

    
    
      
        ftp.banner:"example.com"
      
      
      
Searches for FTP servers associated with the target.

    

    
    
      
        http.html:"example.com" AND product:"Apache"
      
      
      
Finds outdated Apache servers hosting content for the specified target.

    

    
    
      
        http.html:"example.com" AND "default password"
      
      
      
Detects systems associated with the target using default credentials.

    

    
    
      
        http.title:"example.com" AND "admin panel"
      
      
      
Lists exposed admin panels for the target website.

    

    
    
      
        http.title:"example.com" AND "vuln:XSS"
      
      
      
Finds systems vulnerable to Cross-Site Scripting under the specified target.

    

    
    
      
        http.title:"example.com" AND "vuln:RCE"
      
      
      
Searches for systems with Remote Code Execution vulnerabilities associated with the target.

    
  






  
    Open Redis Instances
    Vulnerable Web Apps
    Exposed RDP Services
    Exposed SNMP Devices
    IoT Devices with Default Credentials
    SMTP Open Relays
    VPN Services with Vulnerabilities
    Exposed Elasticsearch Servers
    Exposed Cameras
    Exposed MySQL Databases

    
    
      
        hostname:"example.com" AND port:6379
      
      
      
Finds open Redis instances associated with the target domain.

    

    
    
      
        http.html:"example.com" AND "vulnerable"
      
      
      
Searches for vulnerable web applications hosted on the target domain.

    

    
    
      
        hostname:"example.com" AND port:3389
      
      
      
Identifies open Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) services linked to the target.

    

    
    
      
        hostname:"example.com" AND port:161
      
      
      
Finds Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) devices associated with the target.

    

    
    
      
        http.html:"example.com" AND "default password"
      
      
      
Searches for IoT devices under the target domain using default credentials.

    

    
    
      
        hostname:"example.com" AND port:25
      
      
      
Identifies open SMTP relays connected to the target domain.

    

    
    
      
        http.html:"example.com" AND "vpn"
      
      
      
Finds VPN services hosting vulnerabilities on the target domain.

    

    
    
      
        hostname:"example.com" AND port:9200
      
      
      
Searches for exposed Elasticsearch servers linked to the target.

    

    
    
      
        http.title:"example.com" AND "webcam"
      
      
      
Finds exposed cameras or video feeds hosted under the target domain.

    

    
    
      
        hostname:"example.com" AND port:3306
      
      
      
Identifies MySQL databases that are exposed and associated with the target.

    
  



  

  

    

    
		
		
		
Censys Tool


Censys is a powerful search engine for discovering and analyzing every device and server on the internet. It helps security professionals, researchers, and system administrators monitor the exposure of their systems, assess vulnerabilities, and track internet infrastructure in real time. Censys is designed to provide detailed information about hosts, their services, and configurations based on the data it collects through continuous scanning of the internet.



What is Censys?
